Easily create and add forms to WordPress. Fields are easy to add

option_id: If you find this plugin useful to you

option_id: • Backup/restore tool. You can backup/restore all your forms or single forms and settings.See FAQ
• Easy to hide subject and message fields for use as a newsletter signup.
• Send mail to single or multiple contacts.
• Optional - redirect to any URL after message sent.
• Optional - posted data can be sent as a query string on the redirect URL. See faq

option_name: XHTML
option_value: HTML STRICT
column5: and WAI Accessibility.

option_id: • Reloads form data and warns user if user forgets to fill out a field.
• CAPTCHA can be turned off or hidden from logged in users and or admins.
• Auto form fill for logged in users.
<li>New PHP Sessions are no longer enabled by default allowing for best compatibility with servers
option_name: caching
option_value: themes
autoload: and other plugins. This should resolve any PHP sessions related issues some users had.

option_id: • New added filter hooks for 3rd party plugins and custom modifications.
<li>New more optimized HTML indents when view source
option_name: added ID tags to form elements.

option_id: • New setting on the Advanced tab to enable a \"view / print message\" button after message sent. This feature will be skipped if the \"redirect after the message sends\" is also enabled.
• New Default CSS style for 'labels on top' is now responsive(note:your theme style has to be responsive also).
<li>New improved Styles tab with internal or external CSS Style feature

tags
option_value: and field options. You no longer have to escape comas in form labels and options.

autoload: select-multiple field types: If you add options as a key==value set (use == to separate) the value will show on the form and the key will show in the email.

option_id: • New field Setting: \"Hide label\" check this setting if you want to hide the field label on the form.

<li>New field setting: \"Default as placeholder\" Check this setting if you want the default text to be a placeholder inside the form field. The placeholder is a short hint that is displayed in the input field before the user enters a value. Works with the following input types only: name
option_name: email
option_value: subject

option_id: • New 'Reset Styles on all forms' button to the Tools tab.
• New setting to skip names of non-required and unfilled-out fields in emails.
• Sends Email with UTF-8 character encoding for US and International character support.
• Pre-fill in form fields from a URL query string. See FAQ

option_name: or export to CSV or Excel. See FAQ
Appointment Booking and Free Invoicing via vCita:

option_name: or at the bottom of every page

option_id: • Makes sure the contact form was posted from your blog domain name only.
<li>Email message footer shows blog username(if logged on)
option_name: Date/Time timestamp
option_value: IP address
autoload: and user agent (browser version) of user who contacted you.

option_id: • Uses Open-source free PHP CAPTCHA library by http://www.phpcaptcha.org (customized version included)

option_name: angled
option_value: distorted

option_id: • CAPTCHA can be disabled on the 'Security' tab.
• Works with Wordpress 3.4.2+ and WPMU (Wordpress 4+ is highly recommended)

option_name: Add New menu in WordPress
option_value: or upload the si-contact-form folder to the /wp-content/plugins/ directory.

option_id: • Activate the plugin through the Plugins menu in WordPress. On the Admin screen use the Plugins side menu to select FS Contact Form to configure the forms.
• You must add this shortcode [si-contact-form form='1'] in a Page
option_name: Post
option_value: or Text Widget. You can find this shortcode on the Basic Settings tab of any form. Here is how to add the shortcode: Log into your blog admin dashboard. Click Pages
column5: add a title to your page
column6: enter the shortcode [si-contact-form form='1'] in the page. Uncheck Allow Comments

option_id: • Updates are automatic. Click on \"Upgrade Automatically\" if prompted from the admin menu. If you ever have to manually upgrade
option_name: simply deactivate
option_value: uninstall
autoload: and repeat the installation steps with the new version.

option_name: be sure to properly configure the email settings on the Basic Settings tab:

option_id: Read the following instructions and watch the YouTube video below:

Set the \"Return-path address\" setting to a real email address on the SAME domain as your web site. This step really is ALWAYS necessary so mail is properly identified as originating from your server. For best results the \"Email To\" and the \"Return-path address\" should ALWAYS be separate REAL email addresses on the SAME DOMAIN as your web site (don't skip this important step!).
Some people will like to set the \"Email To\" to a gmail.com
option_name: outlook.com
option_value: or some other webmail address (if that is what you want
column5: but the \"Return-path address\" should ALWAYS be set to a real email addresses on the SAME DOMAIN as your web site. If you try a webmail address and your mail is not sending
column6: try changing the \"Email to\" address to a REAL email addresses on the SAME DOMAIN as your web site. You can still deliver it to your webmail address by forwarding the email from a setting in your hosting control panel
column7: or configuring your webmail to fetch a mail account.

option_name: check this setting box:

option_id: Enable when web host requires \"Mail From\" strictly tied to site (don't skip this important step!).

option_name: then test your form's mail delivery by sending a message from the form on your page. When testing your form on your page
option_value: do not fill out the email field with the same email address as the \"Email To\" or \"Return-path address\". Use a different email address because some server's security settings do not allow email to send from/to the same address.

option_id: If you have other forms in use
option_name: be sure to repeat these settings for each form.

option_id: Now your email is properly configured for best delivery. Your form Email should now be DMARC compliant for users who submit your form with yahoo
option_name: aol
option_value: comcast
autoload: or any other provider who now requires DMARC compliance.

option_id: The email you receive will appear to be from your site email address
option_name: but because the email header \"Reply-to\" is set as the form user's email address. You should be able to just hit reply and send email back to the real sender. Also you should see the sender's email address in the message content. So it is still possible to send mail to that address if the \"Reply-to\" is somehow ignored by your email program.

option_id: <h4>I just installed this and do not get any email from it
option_name: what could be wrong?
but if you still need help...

option_id:
See the FAQ page: How to troubleshoot mail delivery

• (22 Dec 2014) - Move the filter hook si_contact_email_fields_posted to before Silent Remote Sending.
<li>add new advanced tab setting \"Enable Internationalized Domain Names when checking for a valid email address\". Because this setting relaxes the email validation check considerably
option_name: do not enable unless you have to allow Russian
option_value: Japanese
column5: etc. characters in the email address.

option_id: • Fix so field tags can have upper case characters.
<li>(18 Sep 2014) - Fix the validate email function is updated for new generic top-level domains (gTLDs) released in 2014 and beyond. Allows up to 12 characters like .training
option_name: .photography
option_value: .company

option_id: • Fix so honeypot field slug will never conflict with custom post types.
<li>Add new feature for Default field properties: For the Default setting of a date field type
option_name: you can enter any date in the configured format. Or to show today's date as default
option_value: just put the word today in brackets. example: [today].

option_id: • (13 Sep 2014) - Fix error 'Invalid argument supplied for foreach' when add new form.
• Increase z-index for the calendar pop up.
• (09 Sep 2014) - Fix 'After form additional HTML' was not printing on form.

<li>Fix to check for conflicting post types and show a warning. None of the field slugs can be the same as a post type rewrite_slug or you will get \"page not found\" when posting the form with that field filled in. In this new version
option_name: if you have this conflict there will be a warning on the form and on the form edit page. Warning: one of your field tags conflicts with the post type redirect tag \"tag name\". To automatically correct this
option_value: click the \"Save Changes\" button on the form edit page. Also the form editor will not let a conflict happen while editing
autoload: but a conflict can still happen if you add custom post types. So if you add any custom post types
column5: be sure to check your forms for any warning messages.

option_id: <li>(24 Aug 2014) - Added a new setting on the Advanced tab \"Enable to prevent double click on submit button.\" It is enabled by default.
This setting disables the Submit button after click
option_name: to prevent double click on the button. Also prevents going back and submitting the form again. Note: this setting is ignored if the \"Are you sure?\" popup for the submit button is enabled
option_value: or when you have filled in the Submit button input attributes setting with a \"onclick\" attribute.

option_id: • Fixed tags were sometimes showing in confirmation email.
• Fixed Success page additional HTML shows outside of fieldset box.
• (11 Aug 2014) - Fix 'Add New Field' button not working on German translation. last fix was not working.
• (10 Aug 2014) - Fix 'Add New Field' button not working on German translation.

<li>Added Silent Conditional Field and value settings for the silent send feature on the Advanced tab. Use this optional setting to conditionally disable silent sending unless this field tag and value are selected and submitted. Example usage: Your form has a checkbox to \"signup for our newsletter\" with the tag \"signup-newsletter\". You do a silent send to MailChimp to sign up people to the newsletter but you want to disable the silent send if the checkbox is left unchecked. For this example you will set the Silent Conditional Field to \"signup-newsletter\" and the Silent Conditional Value to \"selected\"
option_name: this will only match the field tag and value when the checkbox is selected on the form.

option_id: • (05 Aug 2014) - Added \"Success page additional HTML\" setting to the Advanced tab. This is printed on the success page after the message sent text. Useful for tracking a conversion with Google Analytics. Put the Google Code for Conversion Page here. HTML is allowed.
• Fixed email DNS check setting was ignored.
• (21 Jun 2014) - Fixed broken \"Disable email sending\" for data export.
• Bug fix: ampersand and quotes were showing as entity in the To: name in the email.
• (15 May 2014) - Removed themefuse ad (their site was flagged by Google as possibly infected).
• Bug Fix: the 'follow' feature was not working correctly if fields were re-sorted.
<li>New feature: When Name field is set to \"First Name

<h4>I just installed this and do not get any email from it
option_name: what could be wrong?

option_id: See FAQ page: How to troubleshoot email delivery

option_name: will my forms and settings be lost?
it will automatic import of settings from versions 2.5.6 up to 3.xx. As long as you do not use the delete button when deactivating the plugin.

option_id: You can and should make a backup of your forms.

option_name: to 4.xx and my forms and settings did not import

option_id: The forms should have imported. In some rare cases
option_name: they don't import. Sorry for any inconvenience.
click the button on the Tools tab \"Import forms from 3.xx version\".

option_id: More help is on this help page:
I upgraded to 4.xx version and my forms did not import

option_name: where are the settings stored?

option_id: The upgrade is run automatically only once after installing or upgrading the 4.xx version over a 3.xx versions.
The 4.xx version uses different wp options settings than 3.xx
The options settings are rows in the wp_options database table.

option_name: the installation looks to see if 4.xx options are not present(first time install)
option_value: and if 3.xx options are present(3.xx was installed previously)
autoload: if it passes both those tests
column5: then it runs the import code in

option_id: How do I backup or restore my forms?
On the Tools settings tab is a backup / restore tool.

The backup / restore feature can be used for backups or as a site to site transfer. You can back up ALL forms and transfer ALL forms to the same or new site using the restore feature. Or you can back up individual forms and restore them to the the same or new site replacing any one form selected during the restore. Please consider that restoring one form or ALL forms makes permanent replacements to the forms already on the site you restore them to.
Is this plugin available in other languages?

option_name: you need to obtain or make the language file for it.

option_id: At this point it would be useful to read Installing WordPress in Your Language from the Codex. You will need an .mo file for this plugin that corresponds with the \"WPLANG\" setting in your wp-config.php file. Translations are listed below -- if a translation for your language is available
option_name: all you need to do is place it in the /wp-content/plugins/si-contact-form/languages directory of your WordPress installation. If one is not available
option_value: and you also speak good English
autoload: please consider doing a translation yourself (see the next question).

option_id: The following translations are included in the download zip file:
• Arabic (ar) partial translation - Translated by Jasmine Hassan
• Farsi(Persian)(fa_IR) partial translation - Translated by Ramin Firooz

option_name: Israel (he_IL) - Translated by Asaf Chertkoff FreeAllWeb GUILD

option_id: • Italian (it_IT) - Translated by Gianni Diurno
• Norwegian Bokmal (nb_NO) - Translated by Tore Johnny Bratveit

option_name: Taiwan (zh_TW) - Translated by [Cjh]

option_id: How to translate Fast Secure Contact Form for WordPress
Is it possible to update the translation files for newest version?
How to update a translation of Fast Secure Contact Form for WordPress
For more help... See the official FAQ at FastSecureContactForm.com
What is the \"Schedule an appointment\" button on my contact form?
You can extend your contact form to let your users to schedule appointments based on your availability.
Learn more about Why should I add Online Scheduling to my website
You can enable or disable this option in the \"Scheduling\" tab of your contact form plugin settings page.

If you have additional questions visit vCita Support Page

option_name: you can now go to your profile and log out everywhere.

option_id: Vine embeds
Embedding videos from Vine is as simple as pasting a URL onto its own line in a post. See the full list of supported embeds.
Plugin recommendations
The plugin installer suggests plugins for you to try. Recommendations are based on the plugins you and other users have installed.

option_name: date
option_value: and term queries now support advanced conditional logic
autoload: like nested clauses and multiple operators AAND(BORC).

option_id: The customizer now supports conditionally showing panels and sections based on the page being previewed.
add_theme_support( 'title-tag' ) tells WordPress to handle the complexities of document titles.
Continued improvements to inline code documentation have made thedeveloper reference more complete than ever.

option_name: with the help of these awesome folks. Check out some of their profiles while listening to Dinah Washington on the music service of your choice:
Aaron Jorbin
option_value: Adam Silverstein
column5: Alex Concha
column6: Alex Mills (Viper007Bond)

option_name: again a new high.

option_id: If you want to help out or follow along
option_name: check out Make WordPress and our core development blog.

option_id: Thanks for choosing WordPress. Happy holidays and see you next year for version 4.2!

The nextrelease candidate for WordPress 4.1 is now available for testing.

option_id: Seventychanges have gone in since the first release candidate. With no known issues left
option_name: weplan to release 4.1 tomorrow
option_value: December 18.

option_name: try theWordPress Beta Testerplugin (you’ll want “bleeding edge nightlies”). Or you candownload the release candidate here(zip).If you’d like to learn more about what’s new in WordPress 4.1
option_value: visit the updated About screen in your dashboard ( Aboutin the toolbar) and also check outthe Beta 1 post.

option_id: Plugin authors:Remember to test your plugins against 4.1
option_name: and if they’re compatible
option_value: make sure they are marked as tested up to 4.1. Be sure to follow along the core development blog; we’ve been postingnotes fordevelopers for 4.1 as always.

The release candidate for WordPress 4.1 is now available.

option_id: We’ve made a lotof refinements over the last few weeks. RC means we think were done
option_name: but with millions of users and thousands of plugins and themes
option_value: its possible weve missed something. We hope to ship WordPress 4.1 on Tuesday
column5: but we need your help to get there. If you havent tested 4.1 yet
column6: now is the time! (Please though
column7: not on your live site unless youre adventurous.)

option_id: Think you’ve found a bug? Please post to theAlpha/Beta support forum. If any known issues come up
option_name: you’ll be able tofind them here.
you can use theWordPress Beta Testerplugin or you candownload the release candidate here(zip).If you’d like to learn more about what’s new in WordPress 4.1
option_value: visit the About screen in your dashboard ( Aboutin the toolbar) or check out the beta announcement.

option_name: please test your plugins and themes against WordPress 4.1 and update your plugin’s Tested up to version in the readme to 4.1 before next week. If you find compatibility problems
option_value: we never want to break things
autoload: so please be sure to post to the support forums so we can figure those out before the final release.

option_id: Be sure to follow along the core development blog
option_name: where we’ll continue to post notes for developers for 4.1. (For example: if you’ve written a child theme for Twenty Fifteen
option_value: some of the new pagination functions have been renamed for clarity.)

option_id: Why are we up at this hour?

WordPress 4.0.1 is now available. This is a critical security release for all previous versions and we strongly encourage you to update your sites immediately.

option_id: Sites that support automatic background updates will be updated to WordPress 4.0.1 within the next few hours. If you are still on WordPress 3.9.2
column6: or 3.7.5 to keep everything secure. (We dont support older versions
column7: so please update to 4.0.1 for the latest and greatest.)

option_id: WordPress versions 3.9.2 and earlier are affected by a critical cross-site scripting vulnerability
option_name: which could enable anonymous users to compromise a site. This was reported by Jouko Pynnonen. This issue does not affect version 4.0
option_value: but version 4.0.1 does address these eight security issues:

option_id: • Three cross-site scripting issuesthat a contributor or author coulduse to compromise a site. Discovered by Jon Cave
option_name: Robert Chapin
option_value: and John Blackbourn of the WordPress security team.

option_id: • A cross-site request forgery that could be used to trick a user intochanging their password.
• An issue that could lead to a denial of service when passwords are checked. Reported by Javier Nieto Arevalo and Andres Rojas Guerrero.
• Additional protections for server-side request forgery attacks when WordPress makes HTTP requests. Reported by Ben Bidner (vortfu).
<li>An extremely unlikely hash collision could allow a user’s account to be compromised
option_name: that also required that they haven’t logged in since 2008 (I wish I were kidding). Reported by David Anderson.

option_id: <li>WordPress now invalidates the links in a password reset email if the user remembers their password
option_name: logs in
option_value: and changes their email address. Reported separately by Momen Bassel
column5: andBojan Slavkovi of ManageWP.

option_name: and we’vemade two hardening changes
option_value: including better validation of EXIF data we are extracting from uploaded photos. Reported by Chris Andr Dale.

option_id: We appreciated theresponsible disclosure of these issues directly to our security team.For more information
option_name: see the release notes or consult the list of changes.

option_id: Download WordPress 4.0.1 or venture over to Dashboard Updates and simply click Update Now.
Already testing WordPress 4.1? The second beta is now available (zip) and it contains these security fixes. For more on 4.1
option_name: see the beta 1 announcement post.

Welcome

option_name: so we dont recommend you run it on a production site. Consider setting up a test site just to play with the new version. To test WordPress 4.1
option_value: try the WordPress Beta Tester plugin (you’ll want “bleeding edge nightlies”). Or you can download the beta here (zip).

option_id: WordPress 4.1 is due for release next month
option_name: so we need your help with testing. Here are somehighlights of what to test:
Twenty Fifteen. It’s a clean
option_value: mobile-first

option_id: • A new distraction-free writing mode for the editor. It’s enabled by default for beta
option_name: and we’d love feedback on it.

option_id: • The ability to automatically install new language packs right from the General Settings screen (available as long as your site’s filesystem is writable).
• A new inline formatting toolbar for images embedded into posts.
There have been a lot of changes for developers to test as well:

option_name: date
option_value: comment
column5: including complex (nested
column6: multiple relation) queries; and querying comment types (#12668).

option_id: <li>A single termshared across multipletaxonomies isnow split into two when updated. For more
option_name: see this post
option_value: #5809

option_id: • A new and better way for themes to handle title tags.

option_name: including contextual panels and sections
option_value: and JavaScript templates for controls.

option_id: If you want a more in-depth view of what changes have made it into 4.1
option_name: check out the weekly review postson the main development blog.

option_id: If you think youve found a bug
option_name: you can post to the Alpha/Beta area in the support forums. Wed love to hear from you! If youre comfortable writing a reproducible bug report
option_value: file one on the WordPress Trac. There
autoload: you can also find a list of known bugs and everything weve fixed so far.

WordCamp SanFrancisco is the official annualWordPress conference
autoload: gathering the community every yearsince 2006. This is the timewhen Matt Mullenweg addresses the community in his annualState of the Word presentation a recap of the year in WordPress and giving us a glimpse into its future.

option_id: This year the speaker lineup is stellar. Therewill be talks by three of the lead WordPress developers: Andrew Nacin
option_name: Helen Hou-Sand
option_value: and Mark Jaquith. Were also looking forward to speakers likeJenny Lawson
column5: and Chris Lema. If youre at all interested in the web
column6: you will appreciate the appearance of Jeff Veen one of thecreators of Google Analytics and co-founder of Typekit.

option_id: Even though San Francisco is far far away for most of you
option_name: you can still be part of the fun and watch all presentations in real-time vialivestream:

option_id: Get a livestream ticket and watch all talks from WordCamp San Francisco live

option_name: you can get one of the special livestream tickets
option_value: including a WordCamp San Francisco 2104 t-shirt. You can find all the technical details and start times at the WordCamp San Francisco website.

Version 4.0 of WordPress
column6: named Benny in honor of jazz clarinetist and bandleader Benny Goodman
column7: is availablefor downloador update in your WordPress dashboard.While 4.0 is just another number for us after 3.9 and before 4.1
column8: we feel we’ve put a little extra polish into it. This release brings you a smoother writing and management experience we think you’ll enjoy.

option_id: Manage your media with style
Explore your uploads in a beautiful
option_name: endless grid. A new details preview makes viewing and editing any amount of media in sequence a snap.

option_id: Working with embeds has never been easier
Paste in a YouTube URL on a new line
option_name: and watch it magically become an embedded video. Now try it with a tweet. Oh yeah  embedding has become a visual experience. The editor shows a true preview of your embedded content
option_value: saving you time and giving you confidence.

option_id: Weve expanded the services supported by default
option_name: too  you can embed videos from CollegeHumor
option_value: playlists from YouTube
autoload: and talks from TED.Check out all of the embeds that WordPress supports.

option_id: Writing and editing is smoother and more immersive with an editor that expands to fit your content as you write
option_name: and keeps the formatting tools available at all times.
000 free and open source plugins in the WordPress plugin directory. WordPress 4.0 makes it easier to find the right one for your needs
option_value: with new metrics
column5: and a more visual browsing experience.

option_id: This release was led by Helen Hou-Sand
option_name: with the help of these fine individuals. There are 275 contributors with props in this release
option_value: a new high. Pull up some Benny Goodman on your music service of choice
autoload: as a bandleader or in one of his turns as a classical clarinetist
column5: and check out some of their profiles:

option_name: Aaron Jorbin
option_value: Adam Silverstein
column5: Alex Shiels
column6: Alexander Rohmann
column275: and Zoe Rooney.Also thanks to Michael Pick for producing the release video
column276: and Helen with Adrin Sand for the music.

option_id: If you want to follow along or help out
option_name: check out Make WordPress and our core development blog. Thanks for choosing WordPress. See you soon for version 4.1!

The first release candidate for WordPress 4.0 is now available!

option_name: weve made refinements to what we’ve been working on for this release. Check out the Beta 1 announcement post for more details on those features. We hope to ship WordPress 4.0 next week
option_value: but we need your help to get there.If you havent tested 4.0 yet
autoload: theres no time like the present. (Please
column5: not on a production site
column6: unless youre adventurous.)

option_id: Think youve found a bug?Please post to theAlpha/Beta area in the support forums. If any known issues come up
option_name: youll be able tofind them here.
try theWordPress Beta Testerplugin (youll want bleeding edge nightlies). Or you candownload the release candidate here(zip).If youd like to learn more about whats new in WordPress 4.0
option_value: visit the awesome About screen in your dashboard ( Aboutin the toolbar).

option_name: please test your plugins and themes against WordPress 4.0 and update your plugin’s Tested up to version in the readme to 4.0 before next week. If you find compatibility problems
option_value: please be sure to post any issues to the support forums so we can figure those out before the final release.You also may want to give your plugin an icon
autoload: which we launched last week and will appear in the dashboard along with banners.

The fourth and likely final beta for WordPress 4.0 is now available. We’ve made more than 250 changes in the past month
column5: including:

option_id: <li>Further improvements to the editor scrolling experience
option_name: especially when it comes to the second column of boxes.

option_id: • Better handling of small screens in the media library modals.
• A separate bulk selection mode for the media library grid view.
• Visual tweaks to plugin details and customizer panels.
We need your help.Were still aimingfor a release this month

column5: now is the time and be sure to update the tested up to version for your plugins so theyre listed as compatible with 4.0.

option_name: so we dont recommend you run it on a production site. Consider setting up a test site just to play with the new version. To test WordPress 4.0
option_value: try theWordPress Beta Testerplugin (youll want bleeding edge nightlies). Or you candownload the beta here(zip).

WordPress 3.9.2 is now available as a security release for all previous versions.We strongly encourage you to update your sites immediately.

option_id: This release fixes a possible denial of service issue in PHP’s XML processing
option_name: reported by Nir Goldshlager of the Salesforce.com Product Security Team. Itwas fixed by Michael Adams and Andrew Nacin of the WordPress security team andDavid Rothstein of the Drupal security team. This is the first time our two projects have coordinated joint security releases.

option_id: <li>Fixes a possible but unlikely code execution when processing widgets (WordPress is not affected by default)
option_name: discovered by Alex Concha of the WordPress security team.

option_id: <li>Prevents information disclosure via XML entity attacks in the external GetID3 library
option_name: reported by Ivan Novikovof ONSec.

option_id: <li>Adds protections against brute attacks against CSRF tokens
option_name: reported by David Tomaschik of the Google Security Team.
like preventing cross-site scripting that could be triggered only by administrators.

option_id: We appreciated responsible disclosure of these issues directly to our security team. For more information
option_name: see the release notes or consult the list of changes.

option_id: Download WordPress 3.9.2 or venture over to Dashboard Updates and simply click “Update Now”.
Sites that support automatic background updates will be updated to WordPress 3.9.2 within 12 hours. (If you are still on WordPress 3.8.3 or 3.7.3
option_name: you will also be updated to 3.8.4 or 3.7.4. We don’t support older versions
option_value: so please update to 3.9.2 for the latest and greatest.)

option_id: Already testing WordPress 4.0? The third beta is now available (zip) and it contains these security fixes.

\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";s:5:\"child\";a:2:{s:0:\"\";a:5:{s:5:\"title\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:36:\"Matt: Pope Francis on Climate Change\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:4:\"guid\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:21:\"http://ma.tt/?p=44598\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:4:\"link\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:52:\"http://ma.tt/2015/01/pope-francis-on-climate-change/\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:11:\"description\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:718:\"

He has been called the superman pope
option_name: and it would be hard to deny that Pope Francis has had a good December. Cited by President Barack Obama as a key player in the thawing relations between the US and Cuba
option_value: the Argentinian pontiff followed that by lecturing his cardinals on the need to clean up Vatican politics. But can Francis achieve a feat that has so far eluded secular powers and inspire decisive action on climate change?

option_id:
The Guardian on Pope Franciss edict on climate change will anger deniers and US churches. Definitely the coolest pope in my lifetime.

Oil prices have fallen by about half since June
option_name: making it much cheaper just in time for drivers to fill up their cars for Christmas travel. But the decline in oil prices has had made no perceptible difference on the cost of flying.

option_id:
\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";s:5:\"child\";a:2:{s:0:\"\";a:5:{s:5:\"title\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:72:\"WPTavern: Proposed Enhancements to Distraction-free Writing in WordPress\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:4:\"guid\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:28:\"http://wptavern.com/?p=37456\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:4:\"link\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:82:\"http://wptavern.com/proposed-enhancements-to-distraction-free-writing-in-wordpress\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:11:\"description\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:3711:\"

When we asked readers what they thought of the new Distraction-free writing mode in WordPress 4.1
option_name: a majority of readers responded that it was an improvement. However
option_value: a number of others stated they preferred the old version. Readers also took to the comments to describe their first impression of the feature.

option_id: Distraction Free Writing in WordPress 4.1

option_name: I’ve forced myself to use DFW. When I write content
option_value: I often hit the preview button several times to review changes. This results in DFW mode turning on and off multiple times which I find distracting and at times
autoload: annoying. I’m not the only one who feels this way as Brian Krogsgard of PostStatus.com explains:

option_name: I tend to save and preview the post live a number of times while Im writing
option_value: especially toward the end of my time spent writing.

option_id: It gets a bit dizzying to be fixing typos and saving and previewing while going in an out of DFW.
Id like to see Save Draft and Preview buttons moved into the editor body
option_name: so that I can stay in DFW while finishing up my posts.

option_id: I like the idea of moving the Save Draft and Preview buttons to the post editor. It’s one of the reasons why I reviewed the Distraction Free Preview Button plugin by Alex King. Krogsgard also lists several other ideas with screenshots showing the changes in action
option_name: including:

option_id: • Setting the editor to use the Max-width available

option_name: who reviewed the feature as a user
option_value: suggests similar improvements. One other thing I’d like to see is a full-height editor. It’s annoying when the meta boxes fade away
autoload: the editor remains the same size as if the boxes are still in place. That’s because they are
column5: but I think it would be better if DFW mode would go back to being a separate writing experience so meta boxes are a non-issue.

option_id: I believe if the ideas proposed by Krogsgard and Mylo are implemented
option_name: DFW would likely become the primary mode in which I write content. Until then
option_value:
I’m sticking with the default interface. What you do you think of the proposed ideas and are there any you’d add?

\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:7:\"pubDate\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:31:\"Sat

option_id:
\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";s:5:\"child\";a:2:{s:0:\"\";a:5:{s:5:\"title\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:80:\"WPTavern: JavaScript Leads The Pack in RedMonks Programming Language Rankings\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:4:\"guid\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:28:\"http://wptavern.com/?p=37449\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:4:\"link\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:87:\"http://wptavern.com/javascript-leads-the-pack-in-redmonks-programming-language-rankings\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:11:\"description\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:2289:\"

Research and analyst firm
option_name: <a title=\"http://redmonk.com/\" href=\"http://redmonk.com/\">RedMonk
option_value: released its programming language rankings for January 2015. RedMonk looks at programming language discussions on Stack Overflow and usage on GitHub in an effort to extract insights into potential adoption trends.

option_id: The results from the analysis are not clear indications of general usage but rather
option_name: an examination of the correlation between two populations RedMonk believes to be predictive of future use.

option_id: RedMonk Q115 Programming Language Rankings
It doesn’t surprise me to see JavaScript and PHP so high on the chart
option_name: especially since JavaScript is in the middle of a renaissance. The results also mirror the suggestion that in the future
option_value: 90% of WordPress development could be JavaScript based.

option_id:
Be sure to read RedMonk’s interpretation of the data and the trends worth noting. Also worth reading is Wired.com’s take on the data and the rising popularity of Apple’s Swift programming language. What do you make of the rankings?

\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:7:\"pubDate\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:31:\"Sat

\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";s:5:\"child\";a:2:{s:0:\"\";a:5:{s:5:\"title\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:77:\"Post Status: Ideas for small improvements to the new Distraction-Free Writing\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:4:\"guid\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:30:\"https://poststatus.com/?p=7388\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:4:\"link\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:58:\"https://poststatus.com/distraction-free-writing-wordpress/\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:11:\"description\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:9980:\"

Distraction-Free Writing has been a bit of a controversial feature in WordPress this release. It changed from a you have to toggle to it every time feature to it’s always on feature in WordPress 4.1.

option_name: the DFW experience changed to be more like the regular editor
option_value: well
autoload: because it is the regular editor. It just removesstuff offof the screen that you’re not using.

option_name: with DFW not on:

option_id: The WordPress post editor
option_name: as of WordPress 4.1 (with custom admin theme colors)
with DFW on:

option_id: DFW mode as of WordPress 4.1
Jen Mylo wrote a post about how she doesn’t like the new feature as much as the old one. I’ve seen similar complaintsa few times from folks.
The positive trade-off is that now DFW is much more likely to be used
option_name: since the setting (the four-arrow iconin the upper right corner of the editor box) is persistent for a user once enabled. Previously
option_value: DFW had to be toggled in each use
autoload: and was probably used by a minority of users.

option_id: 4.1 wasthe first go at the feature in its new state
option_name: and I think it’s prettygreat. I’m now using DFW every post I write
option_value: whereas before I almost always forgot to turn it on; plus
autoload: it previously felt like a commitment to the blog post.

option_name: I think Jen’s critique (as well as others’) are noteworthy
option_value: so I decided to take some of the complaints I’ve heard and hack around in the browser inspector to see if I could alleviate them.

option_id: One thing Jen brought up was the height of the editor box. You no longer toggle the height from the bottom corner; instead it auto-adjusts with your content
option_name: and comes shipped with a default height.
and I agree
option_value: that it would be nice if the editor filled the available height of the window
autoload: because right now it feels a bit squished and cramped. Thankfully
column5: we have the viewport height (vh) unit in CSS
column6: and this can be adjusted with pure CSS and a few media queries.

option_id: WordPress DFW mode with full-height content area
I think this is a progressive feature
option_name: so I’d be for using the vh CSS unit not using Javascript on this
option_value: despite the not-great browser support in IE.

option_name: I really like this concept
option_value: even when not in DFW mode. It really calms me down
autoload: not seeing the metaboxes below the post content right out of the gate. We can just keep them right below the editor
column5: just out of sight.

option_id: WordPress post editor with full height content area
Another note Jen made was that she was bothered the editor isn’t centered in DFW mode. Well
option_name: I’ve never noticed that
option_value: but <em>now I do
autoload: ugh. It’s this way because DFW simply hides the right column and admin columns
column5: which are not the same width
column6: and therefore the editor is left with unequal margins.

option_name: during the transition of those admin columns
option_value: theoretically
autoload: we could also move the editor box
column5: though I think we should test what kind of UX effect there is of transitioning the editor your cursor is in. It might not be the most elegant solution.

option_name: here’s what it’d look like once you’re done
option_value: including the full-height editor box.

option_id: DFW full-height editor and centered
I’m iffy on this one. I really don’t like the idea of moving the box you’re actively focusing on. Needs testing.

A critique I learned from another user was that the huge width on the DFW editor box bothered them. I agree. I think we should put a max-width on the editor box — probably whether the user is in DFW mode or not.

option_name: especially in DFW mode:

option_id: We should not let this get so wide. Line length matters!

option_name: with centered content box

option_id: One more idea: what if we inverted the WordPress admin colors
option_name: so that the background was white
option_value: and metaboxes were gray. And then
autoload: we could ditch the “container” of the editor box altogether.

option_name:
with centered editor\" width=\"752\" height=\"431\" />

All white background
option_value: with centered editor

option_id: I think this could look really nice
option_name: but it would require a good bit of admin changes.
based on drafting posts in this mode every day.

option_id: Distraction-Free Writing toggles on and off pretty rapidly as you focus in and out of the editor. When I write
option_name: I tend to save and preview the post live a number of times while I’m writing
option_value: especially toward the end of my time spent writing.

option_id: It gets a bit dizzying to be fixing typos and saving and previewing while going in an out of DFW.
I’d like to see “Save Draft” and “Preview” buttons moved into the editor body
option_name: so that I can stay in DFW while finishing up my posts. Here’s what that looks like:

option_id: DFW with Save and Preview inline
Iteration in WordPress feature development is important. I’m glad we introduced Distraction-Free Writing in the first place
option_name: and I think the changes in 4.1 are worthy. They may need some adjustments
option_value: but it’s a process that will continue to improve.

option_id: Constructive feedback is alwaysgood. The more we use and figure out how others are using various features of WordPress
option_name: the more they can be improved.
I was able to reach out in WordPress Slack and find out the best venue to give feedback
option_value: and if Jen’s post and this one help start a conversation
autoload: the changes can make their way to Trac tickets and eventual patches to make WordPress better.

option_id: I’ve seen at least a handful of folks say “Bring the old Distraction-Free Writing back!” That’sunderstandable; lots of folks don’t like change. Every UI-involved feature in WordPress ever has had critics.
But when you look at WordPress today and WordPress 5 or more years ago
option_name: WordPress today is way more beautiful to use. That’s because the experience the core team has built has iterated over time in response to use
option_value: feedback

option_id:
\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";s:5:\"child\";a:2:{s:0:\"\";a:5:{s:5:\"title\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:39:\"Jen Mylo: Distraction-free Writing Mode\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:4:\"guid\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:26:\"http://jenmylo.com/?p=4787\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:4:\"link\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:60:\"http://jenmylo.com/2015/01/17/distraction-free-writing-mode/\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:11:\"description\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:6729:\"

Once upon a time in WordPress there was a New Feature called Distraction-free writing mode. You accessed it by clicking the icon in the editor toolbar that means full screen pretty much everywhere on the web.
It would load a new screen tha mostly just consisted of a writing box notsurrounded by meta boxes or formatting
option_name: and whatlimited formatting options there were would only appear when you moused out of the writing area. It wasn’t perfect (I would have liked that fading toolbar to have all the same formatting options as the regular editor) but it was pretty non-distracting
option_value: and it just felt calm.

option_id: A while back I noticed some changes in the wp-admin regular editor. All the navigation and meta boxes now faded away while you were writing
option_name: and I thought
column5: kind of a DFW Lite!” I didn’t pay too much attention
column6: as I was just writing a quick post
column7: but in my head I approved
column8: and thought it was a good improvement. Until this morning.

option_id: Most of my blog-based activity happens on work-related blogs that have front-end posting forms
option_name: so it’sbeen a while since I tried to access DFW mode. But I was going to be writing a long post
option_value: and I wanted to go over into that peaceful screen
autoload: so I clicked on the full-screen icon. That’s when I discovered that what I thought was DFW Lite was actually the new DFW. There was no more new screen.

option_value: that’s a lot more efficient. Good for them!” Then I started writing
column5: “[Letters-in-a-configuration-to-replicate-my-slightly-alarmed-and-uncomfortable-sound]!” I hated to admit it
column6: butI felt physically uncomfortable. Am I turning into Sheldon (skip to 3:34)? Crap! Anyway
column7: here’s why I don’t love the new DFW.

option_id: When wp core switched over to the “toolbar anchors to top of editor no matter how long your post” setup
option_name: users lost the ability to grab a corner of the editor and drag it to make it taller. Since it is supposed to automatically resize as you write
option_value: most people thought this was a tradeoff with a net benefit
autoload: and even though I really didn’t want to lose my little corner resize handle
column5: I agreed that the net benefit was worth it. The thing is
column6: if in your head you’ve already thought out a long post
column7: starting in the small box feels cramped
column8: kind of like when you have to repack a sleeping bag and you’re smooshing it with all your might to get it to fit back into the compact stuff sack.

option_id: Think about opening a New Document in MS Word (or equivalent writing program)
option_name: or a writer putting a fresh piece of paper in the typewriter (for those who are too young to remember
option_value: it’s like this). There have been reams written by famous authors in the past about the feeling that action engenders — a feeling of limitless possibilities
autoload: a knock on the creative door
column5: an open road ahead. That’s what DFW tried to emulate. Starting in the small box instead of the full height box feels like possibilities with limits
column6: a creative window that won’t open more than 3 inches for safety
column7: a road with one lane closed for construction.Thoughts scrunch down to try to fit into the available space.

option_id: Even when the box expands to be the height of the screen (minus padding against top and bottom of browser)
option_name: a chunk of space is lost at the top for the toolbar. That fade it used to have really did remove distraction. I wish there had been a way to combine the zen of the fade away (Matt’s original nickname for DFW was zen mode) with the convenience of the always-at-top placement.
the writing window really did have that feeling of a freshNew Document or crisp new sheet of paper. Now
option_value: even once it’s tall
autoload: it’s a bit off-center to the left
column5: because that’s where the editorbox is when on a screen containing navigation and metaboxes.

option_id: There was a time (pre-2000) when I didn’t think too much about alignment in UIs. Then I got a lot of design ideas drilled into my head that stuck
option_name: especially regarding alignment. I like asymmetry in a lot of things
option_value: always have. Hell
autoload: in a site we were just working on one of the things we said we wanted was some asymmetry. But for DFW
column5: the symmetry — the centeredness — was a big part of what made that screen so calming. Your brain didn’t have to do any pattern recognition or internal balancing to make it feel right. But now it skews to the left and it’s driving me crazy
column6: Sheldon style. This isn’t zen for me; it’s a misused apostrophe

option_id: I thought I’d be a holdout forever against using the new wordpress.com posting interface (I have a lot of issues with it
option_name: surprise)
option_value: but
column5: their DFW has that open and symmetrical feeling (even if it has other problems) that makes for a non-Sheldony writing experience.

option_id: So this might be my last post written in wp-admin DFW mode for now. Farewell
option_name: old friend!

option_id: Standard disclaimer when writing about WordPress:This is my personal opinion. I have not been the UX lead for WordPress core for a couple of years now
option_name: so this post on my personal blog should not be seen as representing the WordPress project in any way
option_value:
it’s just my personal experience witha user interface.

\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:7:\"pubDate\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:31:\"Sat

option_id:
\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";s:5:\"child\";a:2:{s:0:\"\";a:5:{s:5:\"title\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:32:\"WPTavern: First Look at SIDEKICK\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:4:\"guid\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:28:\"http://wptavern.com/?p=37315\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:4:\"link\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:42:\"http://wptavern.com/first-look-at-sidekick\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:11:\"description\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:4144:\"

After experiencing a significant delay in late 2014
option_name: the folks over at SIDEKICK have launched a new website along with Composer. Composer is a tool that allows you to create visual
option_value: guided
column5: Ben Fox
column6: showed off the initial demo last year
column7: I described it as the Camtasia of WordPress.

option_id: SIDEKICK has a couple different plans available depending upon how many walkthroughs you want to publish. The free account allows for three published walkthroughs
option_name: 50 monthly plays or views
option_value: 1 active website

option_id: SIDEKICK Activated
The walkthrough creation interface is similar to Camtasia in that it has a timeline with various steps that can be added. To supply audio
option_name: you need to upload a pre-recorded mp3 file for each step. While not as easy as recording the audio within the plugin
option_value: it’s easier to fix mishaps without having to redo the entire walkthrough.

option_id: Walkthrough Interface

option_name: I encountered several things that need to be addressed in future versions. <del>During the initial setup
option_value: there is a box that explains how to build your own walkthrough with a link to get Composer. This leads me to believe that it’s a separate product or plugin when in reality
autoload: it’s not. Composer is part of SIDEKICK out of the box. Update SIDEKICK has already released an update that fixes the copy.

option_id: Old Get Composer Information Box
I encountered a few links which point to a 404 page
option_name: like their Terms of Use. With so many steps in the setup process
option_value: it would be nice if SIDEKICK had a walkthrough of its own
autoload: to guide users on how to configure it. Despite these minor setbacks
column5: they don’t detract from its usefulness. Fox says
column6: the team is already aware of the issues and over the next few weeks

option_name: but once I understood how it works
option_value: I found creating walkthroughs a fairly easy process. With version one out the door
autoload: it will be interesting to see how it’s adopted by theme and plugin developers
column5: considering a number of them already use admin pointers that are built into WordPress. However
column6:
there’s a distinct difference between a simple pointer and walking people through a task.

\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";s:5:\"child\";a:2:{s:0:\"\";a:5:{s:5:\"title\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:13:\"Matt: Fasting\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:4:\"guid\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:21:\"http://ma.tt/?p=44604\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:4:\"link\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:29:\"http://ma.tt/2015/01/fasting/\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:11:\"description\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:1053:\"

“Fasting for as little as three days can regenerate the entire immune system
option_name: even in the elderly
option_value: scientists have found in a breakthrough described as ‘remarkable’.”— <a href=\"http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/10878625/Fasting-for-three-days-can-regenerate-entire-immune-system-study-finds.html\">Fasting for three days can regenerate entire immune system

option_id: Harper’s had a great article on fasting a few years ago it’s not online at the moment but here’s a PDF of it. It’s also common in yoga and folks trying to live longer. I haven’t tried it myself yet
option_name:
but perhaps will at some point this year — I like the idea of doing something by doing nothing.

Working on the right problem is more important than working hard. — Caterina Fake
Found via 84 highlights from The Startup Playbook by Automattician Dave Martin.

The hardest thing in the world is spending the most time on the most important things.

\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:7:\"pubDate\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:31:\"Fri

\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";s:5:\"child\";a:2:{s:0:\"\";a:5:{s:5:\"title\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:38:\"Post Status: A small Medium experiment\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:4:\"guid\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:30:\"https://poststatus.com/?p=7366\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:4:\"link\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:43:\"https://poststatus.com/medium-vs-wordpress/\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:11:\"description\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:9842:\"

I’ve always wanted to write a post on Medium. But I’ve always been too greedy to do so
option_name: because I like to own my content
option_value: and I’ve never had a topic that I really wanted to write about that didn’t better fit on my personal blog or this one.

option_name: so I got to experiment. On hearing that Teehan+Lax shut down
option_value: I felt it was a worthy time to try Medium. I had a bone to pick with their exit post
autoload: and they helped design Medium’s first version
column5: so it seemed fitting.

option_id: Here’s a link to the finished product. Until today
option_name: I had never really done anything to play with their editor beyond look at it and write a few sentences to see the basics of how things worked.

option_id: Medium’s front-end is beautiful. And the back-end looks quite similar. They try to take pretty much everything out of your way to leave you to your words. I like that.
The only problem with simplicity is that it can obfuscate how to actually do stuff. In the case of the Medium editor
option_name: there are two methods to interact with text.
you can click the little plus button
option_value: which allows you to insert a pre-formatted block of something.

option_name: you can highlight text and get a tooltip of formatting options.

option_id: Some of these options are confusing. The tooltip one was fine
option_name: but the + button was tougher. I didn’t know what to expect by clicking the horizontal line or the play button. I thought the code brackets were odd
option_value: as surely not many people are putting code on Medium. It turned out that was an oEmbed button.

option_name: I figured out roughly how to do what
option_value: even insertingthose big full screenimages everyone associatesto Medium.

option_name: these tools are enough. And all in all the experience was delightful
option_value: despite this minor criticism. However

option_id: I like the persistent editing buttons of WordPress (though I could definitely do with fewer options in TinyMCE). I even felt a little weird about Medium’s previews. It’s basically a front-end preview when you edit
option_name: but it’s also not quite teh same. For example
option_value: you don’t get the below post items and other elements that affect the overall feel of the page

option_name: I think the WordPress editing experience could learn from Medium’s efforts
option_value: even if we don’t mimic it entirely. And I do think the recent changes to Distraction writing help get us there.

option_name: most people use WordPress.com’s stats module through Jetpack
option_value: or Google Analytics

option_id: Medium really trims down the stats information. You basically get a few metrics: Views
option_value: Read Ratio

option_id: I love the read ratio stat. Medium’s reliance on reading versus pageviews is pretty well documented
option_name: and I’ve always thought it was great. But what I realized nearly immediately is that this gave me much greater assurance that my post is quality or not
option_value: versus metrics I have available to me with WordPress.com stats or even Google analytics.

option_id: I usually determine quality of my posts based on how many tweets
option_name: comments
option_value: and pageviews I get for an article. This is great
autoload: but just because something isn’t shareworthy doesn’t mean it’s not high quality. Also
column5: if I get 200 views but nearly everyone fully reads it
column6: it’s better than getting 1

option_name: I got views but I didn’t impact. My goal is to impact
option_value: and Medium’s “reads” stat helps me determine that very quickly.

option_id: Referrals are also nice on Medium. I can quickly see where traffic is coming from
option_name: real time
option_value: and go see what that referring source said about my post or take part in the conversations.

option_name: regarding referrals
option_value: is that I can see them per article. This is a feature I would love to see hit WordPress.com stats.

option_id: Hardcore stats folks won’t be totally satisfied with Medium. And to my knowledge
option_name: you can add your own Google Analytics account to your medium account
option_value: so you have to live with what you get. For most of us

option_id: I think there is a ton of opportunity for a solid stats plugin for WordPress that either makes great use of Google Analytics within the WordPress Dashboard
option_name: or rolls their own (outside ofWordPress.com / Jetpack).

option_id: One element I was pretty curious of was exposure. I know that some articles have done really well on Medium
option_name: but I’m not sure what causes that.
the article has had a couple thousand pageviews in a matter of an hour or two
option_value: so that’s great. However
autoload: I think it took off on Twitter and Designer News much more so than from Medium itself
column5: besides recommendations

option_name: it’s like a rolling snowball. I get emails from Medium every day telling me what my Twitter friends recommended on Medium. I imagine that the more people recommend my story
option_value: the more email and other distribution the story gets. That’s good
autoload: because I’ve always figured recommendation buttons were mostly useless on sites
column5: and really only social proof for other would-be readers that are already on some kind of archive.

option_name: Medium doesn’t really have a way to highlight new stories beyond recommendations. And they very much de-emphasize post dates and time-based feeds.
you’re not it

option_id: One last thing was categorization and tags. Medium no longer allows regular users to put a post in any particular category
option_name: as far as I can tell. You have to be some sort of more-certified user or author to put a post in one of their channels or tags or whatever they call them.

option_id: I thought this was a little frustrating. Without some kind of tag
option_name: how can I put my story in a feed that others that don’t already follow me can find? I think it has potential to prevent lesser-known writers from ever being exposed to more eyeballs
option_value: because there is a much smaller initial audience to read their post.

option_name: if I had 100 or 1
option_value: 000 posts on Medium someday
autoload: it would make it harder for me to filter my own stuff. I often go back to certain categories on Post Status to see what I wrote about a particular topic in the past.

option_id: A couple of things that Medium excels at are notes and public previews. I can easily annotate my post in the margins
option_name: without putting the notes in the content (which I often do in WordPress). It’s very similar to Google Docs.

option_id: And public previews and draft sharing is exceptional. I have public preview functionality on Post Status
option_name: and it works okay; it’s built into Medium
option_value: and it has great placement and is easy to use.

option_id: I think WordPress could build these features in. They simply make publishing better. Nearly every site could utilize a tool like this and I think that while there are plugin options for accomplishing these tasks
option_name: it’s pretty core to the experience and mission of publishing.
but not a silver bullet
I liked publishing on Medium.

I don’t own the content. Though they do have a one-click button for exporting everything you’ve ever written. (<em>edit: reader and former Medium employee Evan Solomon notes I do own the content itself. I guess I meanit more in thesense that I don’t own the platform
option_value: andcan’t guarantee my content will always be there.)

option_id: I also can’t use my own domain. If I published there long term
option_name: that would be a problem.

option_id: It’s unfair to compare Medium directly to WordPress. But from a publishing perspective
option_name: I’d say there are definitely elements WordPress could learn from. However
option_value: we shouldn’t just jump completely on the simplification bandwagon.

option_name: in terms of who can definitely learn from Medium
option_value: it’s WordPress.com. If I were going with a hosted platform
autoload: owning my own domain and being able to choose my own theme are pretty much the only reasons I’d choose WordPress.com versus Medium. The overall account (especially) and publishing experiences (marginally) feel more polished on Medium than WordPress.com.

option_id: I don’t know if I’ll publish on Medium again. Probably
option_name: when I find a circumstance that this blog or my personal blog aren’t the right place. It was fun to play with a shiny new tool
option_value: but I’m still a WordPress guy

option_id: \";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";s:5:\"child\";a:2:{s:0:\"\";a:5:{s:5:\"title\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:91:\"WPTavern: The WordPress Foundation Creates a Traveling Scholarship in Memory of Kim Parsell\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:4:\"guid\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:28:\"http://wptavern.com/?p=37415\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:4:\"link\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:101:\"http://wptavern.com/the-wordpress-foundation-creates-a-traveling-scholarship-in-memory-of-kim-parsell\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:11:\"description\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:3126:\"Kim Parsell With the Docs Team Meetup in Cincinnati 2013
Kim Parsell once told me that attending WordCamp San Francisco 2014 was one of the best experiences of her life. It was her first WordCamp San Francisco and although she was unemployed at the time
option_name: she was able to attend thanks to financial assistance received from the WordPress Foundation. Knowing how much it meant to her to attend the event
option_value: the Foundation has launched a new scholarship program in memory of Kim to provide women in the WordPress community the same opportunity.

option_id: The details of the scholarship are as follows:
• It will be a scholarship for a woman contributor with financial need who has never attended the event before.
• It will be limited to WCSFs replacement event rather than available for any WordCamp.
<li>When travel scholarships are announced for the event
option_name: this specific memorial scholarship will be mentioned in the post.
flight
option_value: and lodging.

option_id: • It will be awarded once per year.
• It will be funded by the Foundation.
• It will be awarded by the community team (or whoever within the project is overseeing travel scholarships that year) to the recipient 3 months in advance of the event.

option_name: who helped turn the idea into a reality
option_value: says the program will likely live inside of a broader scholarship program
autoload: “The assumption is that it will live within a broader travel scholarship program that can be worked on this year (SF was a test of the idea
column5: but not intended to be the only WC that would offer assistance in the future if it worked well
column6: which we havent yet worked out).”

option_name: the goal is to encourage more women to get involved with the project. Mylo also explained why it’s limited to first time attendees
option_value: “As a Kim memorial
autoload: we wanted this to be very Kim-specific
column5: and that first-time experience is what we want to provide someone in her memory.”

option_id: Although there was talk of possibly naming a WordPress release after Kim
option_name:
this is a much more fitting memorial as it allows her to contribute to the project for years to come.

\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";s:5:\"child\";a:2:{s:0:\"\";a:5:{s:5:\"title\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:59:\"WPTavern: WPWeekly Episode 177 Hanging Out With GoDaddy\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:4:\"guid\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:44:\"http://wptavern.com?p=37411&preview_id=37411\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:4:\"link\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:65:\"http://wptavern.com/wpweekly-episode-177-hanging-out-with-godaddy\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:11:\"description\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:5253:\"

Over the years
option_name: GoDaddy has become a company people love to hate. Whether it’s poor server performance or the actions of former CEO
option_value: Bob Parsons
autoload: the company has garnered a negative reputation. Within the last two years however
column5: GoDaddy has implemented several changes to turn the company around.

option_name: Marcus Couch and I are joined by three GoDaddy employees:
General Manager of Hosting and Security
WordPress evangelist
developer of the P3 plugin and GoDaddy’s Managed WordPress platform

option_id: We discuss changes made after Bob Parsons stepped down as CEO and how they’ve helped create a new culture within the company. Kurland describes what it’s like to be the first WordPress evangelist and explains his role in helping to establish relationships with people in the WordPress ecosystem. Payne provides details on GoDaddy’s managed WordPress hosting platform and what makes it different from competitors.

option_name: we talk about the decision to remove ticketing and email support in favor of phone and live chat support. We find out the lessons the company learned when it auto activated SIDEKICK on customer’s sites without notifying them. Near the end of the interview
option_value: King shares details on a new product called <a title=\"https://www.godaddy.com/pro\" href=\"https://www.godaddy.com/pro\">GoDaddy Pro
autoload: which will make it a lot easier to manage clients on the GoDaddy platform.

option_id: The biggest takeaway from the interview is that
option_name: GoDaddy has made and continues to make radical changes. It’s not the same company of a few years ago. If you’ve written them off in the past
option_value: I encourage you to give them a second look.

Preview the New Design for the WordPress Themes Directory
WP Email Logs Plugin stores any email sent by the wp_mail() function in a log file within the database. Details logged include: from and to user ids
option_name: from and to email address
option_value: mail subject

option_id: Internal Notes adds a simple textarea to the post and page editors where you can add notes regarding a particular post or page.
FaceBook Feed allows you to easily display a customizable feed of your Facebook Page on the frontend of WordPress.
