\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";s:5:\"child\";a:2:{s:0:\"\";a:5:{s:5:\"title\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:77:\"Post Status: WordPress and the new European Union VAT (Value-Added Tax) rules\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:4:\"guid\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:30:\"https://poststatus.com/?p=7318\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:4:\"link\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:40:\"https://poststatus.com/wordpress-vat-eu/\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:11:\"description\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:16493:\"

On January 1st
option_name: the EU rolled out some new rules for handling the VAT (Value-Added Tax). Let’s start with the obvious: <strong>I’m not a lawyer or accountant and this post is just me chit chatting and doesn’t constitute any official form of advice or whatever other legal disclaimer you need
option_value: consider this it.

option_name: the VAT may be unfamiliar
option_value: but it is relatively similar to an American sales tax. Until now
autoload: non-European businessescould basically ignore VAT (unless they have a European office)
column5: and Europeans were able to utilize the VAT rate of their home office. Now
column6: that’s changing.

option_name: of course
option_value: found some nice loopholes to avoid high VAT rates even when they have a place of business in Europe; they did so by registering their EU operations in Luxembourg
autoload: where the VAT rate islowest. Then
column5: they only had to pay the Luxembourg rate
column6: no matter who they sold to in the EU. <em>The EU is now changing the rules so that the VAT rate of the consumer’s purchasing location is the rate applied
column7: no matter where the merchant is from.

option_id: Getting easy to read information on VAT is hard. The purpose of this post is to provide that sort of information within the context of WordPress. However
option_name: for the best way to read VAT stuff in general
option_value: I’d recommend VAT Live.

option_name: in a nutshell
option_value: is the big deal. Previously
autoload: European merchants knew their own VAT rate and applied that rate to everyone they needed to apply it to. Now there are something like 28 different rates in the EU and merchants have to apply them based on the purchaser
column5: not themselves.

option_name: this sucks. Starting twoweeks ago
option_value: they now have to track a whole lot of stuff and (theoretically) pay taxes to all sorts of entities. The EU has organizations that help with this
autoload: and now there are businesses like Taxamo that are helping handle the calculations and whatnot for these merchants.

option_name: it appears actually complying is hard for small businesses and largeso far. For Europeans
option_value: these rules are a complete mess and is truly going to screw up the digital good economy for European merchants.

option_name: the new VAT rules are a lot fuzzier.

nothing has changed. There have been European rules in place since 2003 saying that non-European merchants should pay VAT when selling to European consumers — even for digital goods. The thing is: they didn’t enforce this because non-Europeans obviously aren’t under jurisdiction of European authorities.
most merchants not in Europe — but selling to Europeans — have ignored existing rules for years
option_value: and we still can. But there is a but. According to some places I’m reading
autoload: there is the potential that American and other non-European governments could cooperate and even enforce European VAT rules on its citizens.

option_id: Is this likely?Heck if I know. I honestly can’t decide if companies like Taxamo are just trying to churn up fear to get more customers (which is natural) or if Americans and other non-Europeans should really pay attention to VAT.
My gut tells me this policy is terrible and won’t last
option_name: at least without some kind of revenue floor (like 1 million Euros or the equivalent per year
option_value: or something). But that change could be years in the making. What until then?

option_name: it really depends on how willing you are to roll the dice. In my heart of hearts
option_value: I hate the idea of paying a foreign government tax revenue for a digitial good when they have no jurisdiction over me.

option_name: though the UK attempts to define qualified services in this document.
I don’t even have to charge sales tax to other states in the US when Americans buy from me. Ugh. So
option_value: I really
autoload: really want to just ignore the EU — as an American at least — and tell them to screw off and catch me if they can.

option_id: There are a few buts this time.
1) It is risky. Because it is possible that the IRS will collaborate withEU member states to collect tax revenue from American digital merchants
option_name: as companies like Taxamo suggest can/will happen. I don’t want to get hit with some kind of audit or fine from the IRS years down the road.

option_id: A friend did make a good point to me recently
option_name: noting that the IRS barely enforces digital goods taxes in the United States
option_value: so why would they do so on behalf of a foreign entity?

option_id: 2) Are European buyers breaking the law if I don’t comply as a seller? I don’t know
option_name: but a friend of mine that is complying brought that up. I can’t find much documentation on this front
option_value: but I wouldn’t want to cause European customers to break their laws by buying from me if I don’t comply.

option_id: 3) It makes my product more expensive to European buyers if I comply
option_name: and it hurts my feelings as an American (Boston tea party
option_value: man!)
column5: services will — and already are — come to save the EU with relatively simple ways to comply.

option_name: each EU member state has to do its own collecting and enforcing. The EU is the regulating body but not the ones that will put feet on pavement to go and enforce these rules and taxes.

option_id: The safe bet seems to be to pay up and deal with it. But I have a feeling you could ignore these rules (if you aren’t European) and probably get by just fine.

option_name: non-EU merchants could just ignore the EU and don’t sell to anyonethere. Well
option_value: I won’t do that. I have a lot of EU-based readers and (potentially) customers. But I am pissed about these rules;the European Union is hurting small businesses

option_id: I feel even worse for my EU-based friends. They don’t even have the option of ignoringEU member states. Penalties for non-compliance for them are even more frightening. They are being excluded as consumers of internationally distributed digital goods and also being pinned down as merchants by these overly cumbersome and irresponsibly drafted rules.
One additional implication of all of this is this: it is now even harder to self-host your eCommerce. If you sell at a marketplace like Etsy or ThemeForest
option_name: they can better (at least attempt to) manage the VAT rules and keep you safe. Though
option_value: from what I’ve heard
autoload: even some big marketplaces are struggling big-time with these new regulations.

option_name: you have to figure out new methods on your own or with your software of choice.

option_id: Complying with VAT has turned into a business opportunity
option_name: and “solutions” are popping up.
you’ll need to learn about VATMOSS. VATMOSS stands for Value-Added Tax Mini One Stop Shop. Basically
option_value: you can register with one EU country and thereafter just deal with that country for quarterly “returns” or payments.

option_name: they have information on registering for VATMOSS.

option_id: The EU member countries will divvy up the differences in taxes collected on their own.

option_name: VoES (VAT on Electronic Services) is also worth learning about if you’re providing “digital services.”

option_id: There are some general needs for your store if you’re going to comply with VAT
• You need to know the country of origin for the buyer
• You need the country of origin for the buyer’s credit card

option_name: some WordPress plugins are playing catchup to make these things possible and / or easier.
information storage is also important. You’re supposed to store this stuff for up to ten years! You are also supposed to have ready-made reports for various authorities.

option_id: Some services are helping with the calculations
option_name: others with the whole gambit.

option_id: The number one player I’ve seen in the VAT compliance market is Taxamo. They are working hard to market their product
option_name: which identifies the consumer’s country
option_value: applies the appropriateVAT
column5: stores and creates reports of your data
column6: and fills out a quarterly return form on your behalf. They do so for 0.20 Euros per transaction
column7: once you surpass 20 transactions per month.

option_id: Taxamo is trying to handle pretty much every part of the handshake for you
option_name: from collecting to reporting. Here’s their flow:

option_id: The EU VAT API is more hands-on
option_name: but probably a nice option for developers looking for a minimilistsolution. Developed by Radish Concepts (savvy readers may recognize WordPress community member Coen Jacobs
option_value: who works with Radish)
autoload: the EU VAT API is a simple
column5: but seemingly elegant solution for the calculation of the various EU VAT rates.

option_id: The EU VAT API has WordPress integration plugins for both WooCommerce and Easy Digital Downloads.
edit: Coen Jacobs tells me that like Taxamo
option_name: the EU VAT API also handles more than just rates
option_value: but they haven’t fully documented all of the other features yet.

option_id: The VAT API is another simple API that looks good
option_name: but I don’t know as much about it.

option_id: The big WordPress eCommerce players pretty much all have VAT compliance methods in place by now:

option_name: and have this extension. But there’s also the Radish Concepts one noted earlier.They also have a super slim extension where customers can enter an EU VAT number
option_value: that uses an API to calculatethe cost. There’s a free plugin on WordPress.org too. Also
autoload: WooCommerce 2.3 is beefing up some features that will make it better capable for handling some of the more nuanced VAT rules.

option_id: Easy Digital Downloads – Has a lot of options. Here’s their site tag for “VAT” that lists the options.

option_name: but it’s not complete yet.

option_id: Jigoshop – I can’t find any references to the new VAT rules
option_name: but since these guys are based in Europe
option_value: surely they either have something or are working on it.

option_id: iThemes Exchange – Has what appears to be an in-house VAT add-on
option_name: up to date for 2015.

option_id: I was interested in who is actually complying with the new VAT rules so far — both Europeans and non-Europeans.
I’ve received 120votes from shop owners selling digital goods in my poll. I think that’s a pretty great response. Here are the results:
Question:Do you have an eCommerce store that sells digital goods? Are you complying with the new EU VAT rules?
I’m a European merchant and complying with new VAT rules
I’m a European merchant and not yet complying with new VAT rules
I’m a non-European merchant and complying with new VAT rules for European customers
I’m a non-European merchant and not complying with new VAT rules for European customers
I’m a non-European merchant and I no longer sell to European customers
I don’t know what you’re talking about
I haven’t decided what to do yet
I guess the numbers aren’t terribly surprising
option_name: though I am quite surprised by how many Europeans are not complying.

option_id: I think most of us will agree that these rules suck. The most organized thing I’ve seen to protest them is the EU VAT Action site. You should go there and see how to petition andparticipate in the debate if you are upset by these changes.

option_name: I have to figure out what to do. My primary reasoning for doing this research was to decide if I need to comply. I wanted to share what I’ve learned with you.

option_id: In addition to the poll I did
option_name: I also asked some friends running businesses. I think you’d be surprised just how many “big” American companies aren’t complying (big in the sense of the WordPress space).

option_id: It does keep coming back to me
option_name: what one friend told me about how easy it was to register for VATMOSS and get his shop setup though. I guess I have a few more days to decide.

option_id: If you haven’t figured out what you’re going to do with your shop yet
option_name: I hope this has helped. If you plan to sell some digital goods in the future
option_value:
this should be a decent guide to get the lay of the land in terms of selling digital goods with WordPress and complying with the new European VAT rules.

\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:7:\"pubDate\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:31:\"Thu

\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";s:5:\"child\";a:2:{s:0:\"\";a:5:{s:5:\"title\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:56:\"WPTavern: Papi Project Adds a Page Type API to WordPress\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:4:\"guid\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:28:\"http://wptavern.com/?p=37377\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:4:\"link\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:66:\"http://wptavern.com/papi-project-adds-a-page-type-api-to-wordpress\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:11:\"description\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:4177:\"photo credit: zenobia_joy – cc

option_name: although generated dynamically in WordPress
option_value: was designed for use with static
autoload: evergreen content. Pages have always been somewhat simpler than posts
column5: which received a major boost to flexibility when custom post types came on the scene in version 3.0.

option_name: a systems developer in Stockholm
option_value: Sweden
autoload: wanted to do more with pages and decided that WordPress needs a Page Type API. He created Papi
column5: an open source project that offers a less traditional approach to working with fields and page types.

option_id: “Papi was started because creating page types didn’t exists in a good way
option_name: ” Forsmo said. “ACF and other plugins only support custom fields on different post types. This is not a good way to create page types. Additionally
option_value: the URL structure isn’t ideal with custom post types.”

option_id: Inspired by the lack of adequate solutions to address this need
option_name: Forsmo spent a year developing Papi in his spare time. The idea for the project is based on EPiServer’s Page Type Builder
option_value: which offers a more object oriented method of building pages. Papi brings this same approach to WordPress.

option_name: it allows you to create page types using an existing post type or using custom post types. It doesn’t have an admin user interface for adding all the fields. “Papi uses classes in PHP
option_value: where one class represents one page type and in your class you add all fields you need

option_name: he discovered that it’s easy to work with when it’s necessary to add new fields. Using Papi’s “page” post type
option_value: you can create different page types with different fields on the same post type
autoload: while maintaining a clean URL structure.

option_id: Forsmo believes that this is the way pages should work in WordPress. Although I don’t know if the idea will catch on with developers
option_name: the project seems useful for those rare scenarios where custom post types aren’t a good match.

option_id: Papi isn’t on the WordPress plugin directory but can be downloaded from GitHub. It’s also available as a Composer package. Papi currently works on WordPress 3.8+ (3.9+ if on HHVM) and PHP 5.3 and above. If you want to experiment with it
option_name: Forsmo has written documentation on how to get started
option_value: how to add page type meta boxes and options
autoload: functions available to use in your page type
column5:
and how to register a page type directory.

\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:7:\"pubDate\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:31:\"Thu

option_id: \";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";s:5:\"child\";a:2:{s:0:\"\";a:5:{s:5:\"title\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:57:\"WPTavern: Edit BuddyPress Activity Posts on the Front End\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:4:\"guid\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:28:\"http://wptavern.com/?p=37251\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:4:\"link\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:67:\"http://wptavern.com/edit-buddypress-activity-posts-on-the-front-end\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:11:\"description\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:3849:\"

option_name: the folks at BuddyBoss released BuddyPress Global Search
option_value: a new plugin that allows users to search through every BuddyPress component. The company’s founder
column5: was inspired to give back to the project by creating a string of free plugins that benefit the whole community.

option_id: BuddyPress Edit Activity is the team’s latest contribution. This plugin is another handy tool that is likely to be useful for a wide range of social networks. It allows users to edit their activity posts and replies on the front end
option_name: similar to the “Edit Post” feature that you see available on Facebook.
you’ll find a new edit option added the activity meta buttons.

option_id: Clicking the button allows users to edit their own activity updates and replies. It gives them the opportunity to correct errors or add to their posts
option_name: instead of having to completely delete the post and start over.

option_id: The plugin’s settings screen lets administrators turn editing on/off for activity posts and replies
option_name: and includes the ability to limit the feature to admins only. The panel also has an option to disable editing after a set number of minutes
option_value: a feature often available in plugins that extend WordPress comments. Setting it to zero makes comments editable indefinitely.

option_id: I tested the plugin and found that it works well and fits in like a natural part of BuddyPress. It automatically adapts to your current active theme and doesn’t force any obtrusive styles on the activity stream.

BuddyPress Edit Activity may seem like a small thing but it’s one of those extensions that adds an intuitive feature that greatly improves interaction between users. This is a feature that users have grown to expect based on experience with other social networks.
BuddyBoss is hitting home runs with its most recent plugin releases
option_name:
both of which are useful for nearly any type of BuddyPress network. The theme shop is strategically positioning itself for becoming more well-known in the market with its indispensable free plugins.

option_id: \";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";s:5:\"child\";a:2:{s:0:\"\";a:5:{s:5:\"title\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:90:\"WPTavern: WP Engine Open Sources Mercury Vagrant for Running WordPress on HHVM and PHP-FPM\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:4:\"guid\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:28:\"http://wptavern.com/?p=37296\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:4:\"link\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:100:\"http://wptavern.com/wp-engine-open-sources-mercury-vagrant-for-running-wordpress-on-hhvm-and-php-fpm\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:11:\"description\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:3808:\"

option_name: in collaboration with the VVV creators at 10up
option_value: released Mercury Vagrant (HGV) today. The new open source Vagrant configuration uses HHVM to serve PHP code. It also includes the ability to run your development site using standard PHP to test against for comparison.

option_id: Mercury Vagrant is useful for any WordPress developer who wants to develop on top of HHVM. Last year
option_name: WP Engine partnered with 10up to launch Mercury
option_value: its new enterprise HHVM WordPress hosting platform. Mercury Vagrant was commissioned to help WP Engine customers with local development
autoload: but it was not designed to be specific to the host’s infrastructure. It is GPL-licensed and meant to be used with any host.

option_name: Mercury Vagrant includes the following:
with built-in documentation
option_value: for running code with either HHVM or PHP-FPM:

option_id: • hgv.dev — General documentation and links for all of the tools
• hhvm.hgv.dev — A new WordPress installation running on HHVM
• php.hgv.dev — A new WordPress installation running on PHP-FPM (PHP 5.5)

option_name: etc.)

option_id: It also includes URLs for testing Varnish caching:

WP Engine labs is committed to supporting and improving Mercury Vagrant for the foreseeable future. The team has collaborated with Facebook to resolve many of the previous issues of using HHVM with WordPress sites. Even if you’re using different host that offers HHVM
option_name: this open source Vagrant configuration is a solid
option_value: professionally-supported tool for local testing. If you need help getting started
autoload: WP Engine created a visual walk through and tutorial videos to help you set up your local machine with HHVM with Vagrant.

option_id:
Mercury Vagrant is a community tool that will go a long way towards helping developers become more familiar with running sites on HHVM. Benchmarks comparing WordPress sites on HHVM vs PHP-FPM indicate a 600% performance increase with HHVM. Dramatic performance increases in this range should have more hosts looking to add support for HHVM in the near future.

\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:7:\"pubDate\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:31:\"Wed

option_name: I Love WordPress
option_value: But I Object to a Marriage\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:4:\"guid\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:28:\"http://wptavern.com/?p=37262\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:4:\"link\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:79:\"http://wptavern.com/i-love-composer-i-love-wordpress-but-i-object-to-a-marriage\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:11:\"description\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:10606:\"photo credit: Jesse Kruger – cc

option_id: This post was contributed by David Hayes. David loves solving difficult problems at Press Up
option_name: publishing new WordPress tutorials at WPShout
option_value: and eating cold cereal with milk.

option_id: The developer tool Composer has been sneaking in around the fringes of the WordPress community. Rarst is a fan. The Roots theme framework folks like it. There’s support infrastructure like WPackagist.
Composer is widely known in the wider PHP development space. Developer types who mostly focus on WordPress probably have some passing familiarity with it. Maybe you ran across a project I mentioned
option_name: or heard about it at a WordCamp or meet-up. Or maybe you’ve seen Sarah’s intermittent coverage here at the Tavern when projects most recently BuddyPress take steps to support it.

option_id: Composer is awesome. I think it’s the most exciting thing to happen to PHP in the last five years. WordPress is awesome. I’ve been using WordPress for nearly a decade now
option_name: and I wouldn’t recommend people use anything else for a beautiful
option_value: feature-rich publishing experience for the web. But I don’t think the two fit together as well as some would like

option_id: But don’t worry if you don’t know what Composer is
option_name: we’ll start with that. Then we’ll cover a bit about why WordPress is great and explain where the two fit together
option_value: sometimes a bit awkwardly. Finally
autoload: we’ll look at how and when it makes sense to incorporate Composer into WordPress work.

option_name: Composer is dependency management for PHP. That is
option_value: it’s the way that I can pull in external code  libraries
column5: whatever you want to call them  that other people wrote
column6: make sure it’s loaded for me to use
column7: and never need to worry about it again. Many other languages have had solutions to this problem for awhile
column9: Gems are very well known. For front-end JavaScript development
column10: there’s some standardization on Bower. Python’s pip has been around awhile. All of these things have similar roles
column11: but the specific implementation is different.

option_id: The big problem dependency managers solve is the way most people deal with dependencies other people’s code they’re using to solve a problem. Without a tool like Composer
option_name: it is sloppy and haphazard. When you want a user-friendly date handling library
option_value: you go to your search engine
autoload: find a few hundred lines of code
column5: copy them into a file
column6: try your best to figure out how to work with them
column7: and never ever know or care when the author of those lines later realizes they created a giant performance bottleneck or security vulnerability.

option_id: Dependency managers also take care of the issue that some code you want to use may itself rely on other libraries
option_name: classes
option_value: etc.
autoload: that you aren’t already using. This leads to big headaches. And in solving these issues
column5: Composer also makes sure that it gets versions of all that software that work for all the various libraries your application makes use of.

option_name: you’re saved from a lot of copy-pasting
option_value: you get super-powers about dependency issues
autoload: and you’re also given a much easier path to get performance improvements
column5: security patches
column6: new features

option_name: for example
option_value: tell Composer you want to use a nice date parsing library like Carbon
autoload: set your code up to load the Composer dependencies for you before you use them (with a simple include ‘vendor/autoload.php'; to use this article’s only snippet of PHP) and you’re set to go. And when Carbon
column5: or another dependency
column6: gets updated
column7: you’ll be able to quickly get the latest version with a simple run of Composer’s update command.

option_name: Ill just say
option_value: succinctly
autoload: that WordPress is an easy-to-use CMS with a rich ecosystem of plugins and themes that make it easy to accomplish a wide variety of goals.

option_id: WordPress is made to be easy-to-use specifically
option_name: for the end user. An average WordPress user
option_value: who is put a little on edge by the mention of PHP code
autoload: is still able to easily change the look or behavior of their site just by installing a new theme and a few of the thousands of great plugins out there
column5: right from the simple user interface. Even for commercial plugins and themes
column6: the user can probably rely on few-click updates. Users get security updates to their core WordPress code without even needing to think about it.

option_id: How Composer and WordPress Can Work Together
As Josh Pollock called out in a great article about Composer
option_name: there are three basic ways WordPress and Composer can be combined:

option_id: • To manage dependencies for a theme or a plugin youre developing
• To manage your themes and plugins used on a site
We’ll take on the last two first
option_name: as they’re the most common way in which people are talking about Composer.

option_id: Why Composer and WordPress Aren’t as Compatible as Peanut Butter and Jelly

So WordPress is great and easy to use for slightly-more-technical-than-average people. Composer is great really really great for developers. Don’t two great things make a new even greater thing? I mean: I love peanut butter
option_name: and I love jelly
option_value: and I think a peanut butter and jelly sandwich is one of the top ten foods invented in America. So why don’t I love the combination of Composer and WordPress?

option_id: It’s not that they’re useless together. I think they can work together quite well
option_name: but I don’t think the solution of “run your whole WordPress site with Composer” that’s creeping into more and more places works well. It takes care of one problem WordPress being awkward to manage and deploy for developer-types by creating another a less-than-great experience for the mortals left with the WordPress site who just want to install this new plugin.

in trying to cram WordPress into Composer were forcing a square peg into a round hole. WordPress focus on end-user ease-of-use  just jump into the admin area and search for a plugin on the WordPress.org repository
option_value: or upload the Zip archive you got from the seller is conceptually at odds with using Composer to install WordPress.

option_name: and frankly the greater knowledge required
option_value: makes it the opposite of a simple experience for most. For a site with dedicated and knowledgeable developers or admins around 24/7
autoload: thats possibly a wise trade off
column5: but for most WordPress sites I see
column6: thats a losing combination.

option_id: When Composer and WordPress are a Good Combination

option_name: I think there’s one place where Composer’s great: when you have some dependencies in a theme or plugin. It’s the combination of WordPress and Composer I’ve tried repeatedly and recommend heartily. It is brilliant. When you’ve got a project that you know doesn’t really need to support down to PHP 5.2
option_value: and where you really do want some helper code
autoload: Composer is fantastic as a way to get that external code and seamlessly keep it up to date. (Autoloading
column5: a Composer feature which we’ve ignored until this point
column6: is also a big perk.)

option_name: I think Composer is great. If you’re making a plugin that would benefit from a great date-parsing library like Carbon
option_value: a Markdown parser
column5: by all means use Composer to pull that in. For more WordPress specific stuff
column6: such as CMB2 or TGM Plugin Activation
column7: it’s far better to pull that from Composer than an old-school copy and paste.

option_id: There’s a Time and a Place for Composer

WordPress and Composer arent useless together; far from it. But the “run your whole WordPress site with Composer” solution is only right for developer-intensive use of WordPress. If you’re using something like Capistrano for deployments already
option_name: go ahead and slot Composer right in beside it. For casual WordPress users
option_value: even those who’ve made or modified a theme or plugin before
autoload: Composer is most likely to end up feeling like awkward-to-integrate overkill.

option_name:
you should know how to use Composer to take care of complex dependencies inside of a plugin or theme and then package up your Composer dependencies in a way that is invisible to the end user. Let them be blissfully unaware that you’ve used Composer at all. Let them keep that smooth and comfortable WordPress flow with core security and easy updates. That way we get the best of both!

option_id:
\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";s:5:\"child\";a:2:{s:0:\"\";a:5:{s:5:\"title\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:55:\"WPTavern: The Features as Plugins First Model Is a Mess\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:4:\"guid\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:28:\"http://wptavern.com/?p=33335\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:4:\"link\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:65:\"http://wptavern.com/the-features-as-plugins-first-model-is-a-mess\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:11:\"description\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:7987:\"

Released in late 2013
option_name: WordPress 3.8 was packed with new features including
option_value: a new theme browser experience
column5: and a redesign of the backend. It’s also the first release to include a feature using a new formal development process calledfeatures-as-plugins first. The backend redesign started off as a plugin called MP6 with development beginning in March

option_name: features were largely developed inside of core during the development cycle. This method caused some versions to be delayed
option_value: as was the case for WordPress 3.6. The success of MP6 proved that by developing core features as plugins first
column5: manage
column6: and merge into core at the appropriate time. Since adopting the development process
column7: at least seven features have landed in core. However
column9: the process seems to be falling apart.

option_id: MP6 WordPress Admin Plugin

option_name: Matt Mullenweg and Matt Thomas released a new version for people to test. They also kept everyone updated on what changed and left the comment form open to solicit feedback. This made it easy for people to participate in the development and testing process. By using P2 and the comment section
option_value: it was a lot easier to provide feedback. Since MP6 was a plugin
autoload: testing it was as easy as installing it on a stable version of WordPress.

option_id: MP6 was available for download on the WordPress plugin directory. This made it accessible to anyone who wanted to test it. Recent plugins like the User Session Manager byJohn Blackbourn don’t have any P2 posts on the Make WordPress Core site. As with several other features
option_name: discussion took place within a trac ticket. Development of the plugin was handled on Github until it received a pass to be merged into core. Having a feature plugin only available on Github and a lack of communication surrounding the feature prevents a lot of people from potentially being part of the testing group.
Ryan Boren
option_value: noted in an open thread in November of 2014
autoload: that when it comes to gathering a testing audience
column5: no feature plugin has reached the standards set by MP6. For plugins to be merged into core
column6: Boren suggested the following items should be met:

option_id: • Be present and up-to-date in the plugin directory.
• Be as ready to go on mobile as they are on desktop.
• Have visual records for major flows through all new interfaces on all devices.
• Have mature UI that isnt going to derail the release train.
• Have a history of posting weekly updates to make/core.
• Have a history of regular plugin directory updates.
• Publish a merge consideration post on make/core complete with visual records and other diligence.
• Exist for at least one release cycle. Plugins created at the beginning of a release cycle should not be considered for merge until the next release.
Several feature plugins fail to adhere to many of these proposed guidelines. In June of 2014
option_name: Andrew Nacin added a “Beta Testing” tab to the add plugins screen for those who use WordPress trunk. The tab lists Feature Plugins that are available for testing.

option_id: Feature Plugin Development Looks Dead
Based on the results in the screenshot
option_name: it looks like every feature plugin is dead in the water
option_value: including the WP API. However
autoload: if you look at the activity for WP API on Github
column5: there’s plenty of development taking place. How can more people participate in the testing process if feature plugins are not routinely updated and available for download in the directory? This needs to change sooner rather than later.

option_id: Feature plugins are not guaranteed to be added to WordPress. Instead
option_name: the process is similar to a lab with each one being an experiment. Sometimes a plugin won’t be added but parts of it will. For example
option_value: many of the improvements to the post editor in 3.9
column5: and 4.1 are derived from the Front-end Editor. Maybe the core team should think about renaming them to feature experiments as it’s more representative of what they really are.

option_id: When I brought up the subject of feature plugin development at the January 7th core development meeting
option_name: Scott Taylor made an excellent point
option_value: “F<span class=\"message_content\">eatures-as-plugins often become Projects without requirements or tasks
column5: and then often require all-or-nothing to go in.” Feature plugins are generally driven by one or two people who might be good developers
column6: but lack project management skills. It’s almost like someone needs to constantly shepherd feature plugins to make sure they’re following a schedule and keeping them all on the same page.

option_id: It’s clear that the feature plugin development process is disjointed at best. Communication is lacking
option_name: synchronized development between plugins on Github and WordPress.org is non-existent
option_value: and some plugins are merged too quickly. If users are to receive the maximum benefits from the experimental process
autoload:
it needs to be orchestrated better. At least the core team is aware of the problems and is working towards improving the situation for the 4.2 development cycle.

option_id:
\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";s:5:\"child\";a:2:{s:0:\"\";a:5:{s:5:\"title\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:28:\"Matt: Futuristic Predictions\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:4:\"guid\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:21:\"http://ma.tt/?p=44568\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:4:\"link\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:44:\"http://ma.tt/2015/01/futuristic-predictions/\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:11:\"description\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:336:\"

option_name: so here io9 lists The Most Futuristic Predictions That Came True In 2014
option_value: including technologically-assisted telepathy
column5: laser weapons
column6:
and landing a robot on a comet.

\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:7:\"pubDate\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:31:\"Wed

option_id: \";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";s:5:\"child\";a:2:{s:0:\"\";a:5:{s:5:\"title\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:101:\"WPTavern: Justin Tadlock Joins Forces with Emil Uzelac to Provide WordPress Theme Review as a Service\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:4:\"guid\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:28:\"http://wptavern.com/?p=37204\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:4:\"link\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:111:\"http://wptavern.com/justin-tadlock-joins-forces-with-emil-uzelac-to-provide-wordpress-theme-review-as-a-service\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:11:\"description\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:5464:\"photo credit: pollas – cc

option_name: Emil Uzelac launched a new theme review service targeted at WordPress developers and companies that want their products to adhere to best practices. Just one week after launch
option_value: Justin Tadlock
autoload: a fellow member of the WordPress.org theme review team and author of the Hybrid Core framework
column5: is joining forces with Uzelac to provide professional reviews to customers.

option_id: “Im interested in seeing where this goes. We (DevPress when I was there) were going to offer this service. It never took off because the business itself didnt
option_name: ” Tadlock commented on the original announcement. In the past he has conducted paid reviews privately for commercial theme vendors. Uzelac noticed his interest and pounced on the opportunity to partner with him.

option_id: “To quote one of my all time favorite businessman
option_name: J.C. Penney: ‘Growth is never by mere chance; it is the result of forces working together
option_value: '” Uzelac said. “Justin and I exchanged a few ideas in my launching interview and that is where I learned from Jeff that he had this idea back in 2011.”

option_id: Since this idea has been on Tadlock’s mind for several years
option_name: he didn’t hesitate to get involved. “It’s something I pretty much immediately hopped on.  We already have a bit of a working relationship as admins for the Theme Review Team.  I believe it’s a good fit

option_id: Based on his experience at ThemeForest and his service on the WordPress.org Theme Review Team
option_name: Tadlock is convinced that developers of all experience levels can benefit from professional theme review:

option_id: Professional theme authors who want to bring the highest quality theme to market need assurance that their code is solid. There’s nothing worse than spending months building an awesome theme only to have it break for a bunch of users because you missed something minor. Even the most experienced theme authors (myself included) overlook problems that a fresh
option_name: second pair of eyes could easily find.  We have editors for books
option_value: newspapers
autoload: and so on for the same reason.  Authors
column5: whether they’re writers or theme developers
column6: are going to miss something.

option_id: Although themes have always been critical to the success of WordPress
option_name: theme review is just now emerging as a service for which one might want to hire a dedicated professional. Tadlock attributes this to the increasing complexity of theme development. “Themes are a lot more complex than they were just 5 years ago
option_value: for example.  This isn’t just because theme authors are packing in more stuff

option_id: “Part of it is because basic WordPress theme development has gotten more complex. WordPress has been packing in a lot of new things in recent years
option_name: and themes need to account for a variety of possibilities. Just having someone running through unit tests will be a big help.”

option_id: Several readers commented on the original announcement to suggest that Uzelac consider offering a certification or badge of some sort for commercial theme authors to display once their themes have passed a professional review. Tadlock is open to the idea but sees it more as a marketing tool for their customers to employ.

option_name: but I don’t think that’s what really matters
option_value: ” he said. “I think the focus should be on giving our clients (theme devs) peace of mind.  Once we are seen as a legit and well-known service
autoload: a badge or something will most likely become a useful marketing tool for theme authors.”

option_id: The Theme Review service has already gained traction
option_name: and Uzelac reports that he completed his fourth review today. “I’ve taken only what I could handle alone and in time. Now that Justin is in
option_value: we will do more
autoload: ” he said. “In only few days after the initial launch the response and support has been overwhelming. This confirms that our community is in great need of experienced reviewers.”

option_id: When it comes to WordPress theme review skills and experience
option_name: Uzelac and Tadlock’s forces combined are unparalleled in the WordPress community. Tadlock hopes that together they can expand their efforts to serve more commercial theme providers. “I’d like to see regular business from some of the major theme shops
option_value:
” he said. “That’s probably the biggest goal I’d shoot for at the moment.”

\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:7:\"pubDate\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:31:\"Tue

option_id: \";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";s:5:\"child\";a:2:{s:0:\"\";a:5:{s:5:\"title\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:52:\"WPTavern: VersionPress RC1 Released to Early Backers\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:4:\"guid\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:28:\"http://wptavern.com/?p=37215\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:4:\"link\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:62:\"http://wptavern.com/versionpress-rc1-released-to-early-backers\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:11:\"description\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:3708:\"Version Control Featured Image

option_name: the plugin that allows you to revert changes to a site without having to restore a backup
option_value: is being released to early backers. Near the middle of 2014
autoload: VersionPress creators Borek Bernard and Jan Vorek created a crowdfunding campaign asking for $30K.

option_id: The campaign started off on a rocky note
option_name: as several readers questioned what license the plugin would use. Bernard decided to license the plugin using the GPLv2
option_value: but the decision was made near the middle of the campaign and the duo missed their goal by $14.5K. However
column5: for the past several months
column6: the team has been hard at work getting the product to a point where people can start using it.

option_id: A release candidate will be made available later this week to those who backed the project with $50 or more. If no major issues are reported
option_name: the team will release version 1.0 by the end of the month. However
option_value: the plugin will not be free to use. Those who want access to version 1.0 and future releases will need to join the early access program. The program tries to strike a balance between making the plugin accessible to anyone who’s interested and funding development.

option_id: Early Access Program Prices
VersionPress 1.0 is an initial release and won’t have all of the planned features such as sync and staging. Instead
option_name: those features will be rolled out in future versions of the product. According to their development plan:

option_id: • Version 1.0 will contain all the important basics things like Undo
option_name: Rollback
option_value: automatic change tracking
autoload: support for all the built-in WordPress types
column5: etc.

option_id: • Version 2.0 will bring full support for sync and staging.

option_name: 4.0 etc. will bring features from the roadmap.

option_id:
I’m happy to see the duo remain committed to their goal of developing and shipping a working product. I still think VersionPress is a great idea and can’t wait to see how easy or difficult it is to use. Look for a thorough review on the Tavern sometime in February.

\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:7:\"pubDate\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:31:\"Tue

\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";s:5:\"child\";a:2:{s:0:\"\";a:5:{s:5:\"title\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:53:\"WPTavern: Is 2015 The Year of WordPress Admin Themes?\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:4:\"guid\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:28:\"http://wptavern.com/?p=37098\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:4:\"link\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:62:\"http://wptavern.com/is-2015-the-year-of-wordpress-admin-themes\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:11:\"description\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:3370:\"

The CPO and partner of Human Made
option_name: Noel Tock
option_value: published his WordPress predictions for 2015. His predictions include
column5: front-end editing
column6: internationalization
column7: and more. This could be the year of admin themes
column8: but I think it largely depends on whether the WP API is merged into core.

option_id: Tock predicts we’ll see a substantial increase in different WordPress backend experiences. Although there are implementations like Happytables and Jetty which use the WP API
option_name: I don’t think we’ll see a lot of adoption until it’s vetted and merged into core.
Tock makes a great point when he says:
premium custom dashboards will fail. If its too generic
option_value: it likely cant compete with WP-Admin (which actively pursues one size fits all). On the other hand
autoload: if its too niche or not very extendable
column5: it wont be of much use either. A minimal small business dashboard with front-end editing will likely be the most popular seller.

option_name: I think his advice to those looking to experiment with the API should be considered
option_value: “Dont create a custom dashboard because you want to change the way it looks
autoload: change it because you significantly want to improve the experience of your users.”

option_id: Jason Schuller’s admin design for Pickle is a great example of a backend that correlates with what’s on the frontend. Everything that’s unnecessary to manage the frontend of the site is removed from the backend
option_name: creating a streamlined experience.

option_id: WordPress Backend For The Pickle Theme
The WP API will make it easy for developers to create a variety of different admin experiences
option_name: but users will ultimately decide which implementation is right for them. We may even see an entire category added to the WordPress theme directory for admin themes.

option_id: Whether the API is merged this year or next
option_name: custom admin themes are inevitable. In the future
option_value: there will likely be an admin theme that matches the way you use WordPress to harmonize the user experience. What that theme looks like is anyone’s guess
autoload:
but I’m looking forward to reviewing custom admin experiences created by developers using the API.

\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:7:\"pubDate\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:31:\"Tue

option_id: \";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";s:5:\"child\";a:2:{s:0:\"\";a:5:{s:5:\"title\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:67:\"WPTavern: Better Notifications Plugin for WordPress Now Out of Beta\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:4:\"guid\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:28:\"http://wptavern.com/?p=37180\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:4:\"link\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:77:\"http://wptavern.com/better-notifications-plugin-for-wordpress-now-out-of-beta\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:11:\"description\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:4881:\"
The beta version of the Better Notifications for WordPress plugin was released last year
option_name: and it lay dormant for many months while its original collaborators searched for a new developer. The plugin was created to allow you to send customizable HTML emails to users based on different actions in WordPress.
founder of development agency Voltronik
option_value: commissioned the plugin to be built while creating a custom project management system on top of WordPress. “One of the requirements was for notifications of new projects (WordPress categories) via email. I couldn’t find a plugin that sent notifications for events such as these
autoload: so I decided to write my own
column5: ” McConnell said. He worked with a developer to push the beta out over the course of a weekend
column6: but that’s as far as it went last year.

option_name: McConnell was able to get the plugin out of beta and develop a roadmap for future releases. Version 1.0 is a major overhaul and a complete re-write of the plugin. New features include:

option_id: • Auto-importer: Your old notifications will be imported when updating the plugin
• New ‘Generator’ for easily creating and editing your notifications
• More options and notification types as per feedback via the forums
• Granular control over choosing either user roles or individual users you’d like to send a notification to
Each email can be customized using HTML
option_name: CSS
option_value: and Voltronik’s extensive list of shortcodes
autoload: which means you can add your site’s logo
column5: a simple design
column6: and all kinds of content to the emails. You can also set the notifications to go to selected individual users or limit the notifications based on user roles.

option_id: In addition to customizing WordPress’ default notification emails (i.e. new comments
option_name: registrations
option_value: password reset)
autoload: the plugin adds options for the following:

option_name: published
published
option_value: pending review

option_id: Better Notifications for WordPress adds notification customization options for every custom post type you have registered on your site
option_name: which can be very useful if your CPT-based plugins don’t include notifications.

option_id: If you’re trying to keep a tight rein on new category creation
option_name: this plugin will help keep you in the loop. It also makes it easy to brand your site communications better as an alternative to WordPress’ ugly notification emails. The plugin was built to fit into WordPress like a natural part of the admin.

option_id: McConnell identifies other scenarios where Better Notifications might be useful:
• Outreach: A blog/news site with hundreds of subscribers – use it to alert them of new blog posts

option_name: internal WordPress site – use it to alert staff of new posts and comments

option_id: • Monitor: A website for a new product or service – use it for notifications of pingbacks and trackbacks
• Security: To receive alerts of password reset requests and their corresponding email address
If you need greater control and customization over WordPress’ email notifications
option_name:
this plugin handles just about every kind of notice on actions related to publishing. It’s well on its way to becoming a comprehensive tool and McConnell and his team are eager to improve the plugin based on user feedback. Better Notifications for WordPress version 1.0 is now available for download on WordPress.org.

Okay
option_name: maybe it doesn’t raise the bar the way you think I mean. But this is worthwhile.

option_id: I’m pretty busy building the new Post Status infrastructure
option_name: but not too busy to post this.

option_id: GravityView is a WordPress plugin by Zack Katz and Katz Web Services that lists Gravity Forms entries on your site in a nice way. It’s a slick plugin I’ve been meaning to dig further into since I learned about it at a WordCamp a few months back.

option_name: the folks behind GravityView have hired @songadaymann
option_value: Jonathan Mann
autoload: to create a new video for them
column5: and it is… unforgettable.

option_name: I told you.

option_id: This is the type of “hey this is funny / quirky” will probably better qualify for the members only newsletter in the future. But while I’m building that out
option_name:
you all get this nugget of fun for free.

“They modelled data up to 1970
option_name: then developed a range of scenarios out to 2100
option_value: depending on whether humanity took serious action on environmental and resource issues. […] The books central point
column5: is that the earth is finite and the quest for unlimited growth in population
column6:
material goods etc would eventually lead to a crash. So were they right?” The answer lies in Limits to Growth was right. New research shows we’re nearing collapse.

Ping-O-Matic is all about getting your latest content out into the world and driving more traffic to your blog. Sometimes
option_name: though
option_value: we need inspiration to write.

option_id: Our friends at The Daily Post published a free ebook of daily prompts: a gentle nudge to encourage a regular blogging habit. It’s available in four languages: English
option_name: French
option_value: Spanish

option_id:
Download the version you need — it’s free!


\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:7:\"pubDate\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:31:\"Tue
option_name: 13 Jan 2015 18:16:46 +0000\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}}s:32:\"http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/\";a:1:{s:7:\"creator\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:20:\"Cheri Lucas Rowlands\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}}}}i:27;a:6:{s:4:\"data\";s:13:\"

option_id:
\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";s:5:\"child\";a:2:{s:0:\"\";a:5:{s:5:\"title\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:100:\"WPTavern: How to Customize The Body and Title Font in WordPress Default Themes Without Touching Code\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:4:\"guid\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:28:\"http://wptavern.com/?p=37158\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:4:\"link\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:110:\"http://wptavern.com/how-to-customize-the-body-and-title-font-in-wordpress-default-themes-without-touching-code\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:11:\"description\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:3147:\"

WordPress 4.1 ships with three default themes
option_name: Twenty Thirteen
option_value: Twenty Fourteen
autoload: and Twenty Fifteen. Although the theme customizer enables you to edit a default theme’s colors
column5: header image
column6: and other attributes
column7: it doesn’t give you the ability to change the body and title fonts. If you’d like to easily change fonts in a default theme using the customizer without using code
column8: try the Styleguide plugin created by Ben Gillbanks.

option_name: you’ll see two new options added to the customizer. These allow you to edit the font for the body and title text. Styleguide will let you change fonts for headers and body text in almost any theme
option_value: but out of the box it supports Twenty Ten through Twenty Fifteen. There’s also support for Puzzle

option_id: If you’re using one of the supported themes mentioned above then it will add font and color editing to the customizer
option_name: allowing you to style the themes as you wish. Developers can add support for their own themes by using the ‘add_theme_support’ command. Check out the included theme-styles to see live examples on how to use the command.

option_id: Gillbanks notes that additional theme support will be added in the future. Until then
option_name: if you’re using one of WordPress’ default themes
option_value:
Styleguide is an easy way to add the ability to customize the body and title fonts without touching a line of code.

option_name:
here are two essays by different Automatticians. Steph Yiu writes Still figuring it out: communicating remotely with lots of people and Chris Hardie writes on Distributed vs. In-person Teams.

\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";s:5:\"child\";a:2:{s:0:\"\";a:5:{s:5:\"title\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:94:\"WPTavern: New BuddyPress Global Search Plugin Adds Unified Search of All BuddyPress Components\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:4:\"guid\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:28:\"http://wptavern.com/?p=37106\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:4:\"link\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:104:\"http://wptavern.com/new-buddypress-global-search-plugin-adds-unified-search-of-all-buddypress-components\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:11:\"description\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:2938:\"

The developers behind the BuddyBoss theme shop released a plugin today that has the potential to benefit nearly every BuddyPress social network. BuddyPress Global Search adds a unified search bar
option_name: allowing users to search through every BuddyPress component
option_value: along with pages
column5: and select custom post types.

option_name: the plugin turns the site’s WordPress search inputs into a global search
option_value: capable of returning results for any of the social content on the site. It also features a live dropdown of results as you are typing.

option_id: The plugin’s settings page allows administrators to include or exclude any component or custom post type from the unified search.
The plugin was designed to work with any theme out of the box and should adopt your theme’s styling for BuddyPress search results. However
option_name: every theme is different and it may require additional tweaking to get it to perfectly compliment your current design.

option_id: I spoke with BuddyBoss founder Michael Eisenwasser
option_name: who said that the plugin is his company’s way of giving back to one of WordPress’ sister projects. “I saw Matt at WCSF talking about WP companies giving back 5%
option_value: and was inspired to give back to BuddyPress
autoload: ” he said. “Better search has always been lacking in BP. We built this one because we would use it ourselves on pretty much any site.”

option_id: Eisenwasser plans to continue improving BuddyPress Global Search and will add new features based on user feedback. The BuddyBoss team is cooking up a string of free plugins and next on deck is one that will allow users to easily edit BuddyPress activity on the front end.
If you administer a BuddyPress site and want your search results to return content from the social network
option_name:
this plugin offers a solid option. Download BuddyPress Global Search for free from WordPress.org. Documentation and support can be found on the BuddyBoss website.

\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";s:5:\"child\";a:2:{s:0:\"\";a:5:{s:5:\"title\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:67:\"WPTavern: Preview the New Design for the WordPress Themes Directory\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:4:\"guid\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:28:\"http://wptavern.com/?p=37090\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:4:\"link\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:77:\"http://wptavern.com/preview-the-new-design-for-the-wordpress-themes-directory\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:11:\"description\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:3730:\"

A long-awaited update to the official WordPress Themes Directory is in progress. Contributors on the Meta team for WordPress.org are picking up speed on the effort to move the theme repository away from bbPress and into a new plugin
option_name: comprised of a custom post type for the repository package and a theme uploader.

option_id: Konstantin Obenland posted a project update to inform contributors that both the theme and the plugin that help to power the directory are now open source and available for anyone to view on meta.trac. The plan is to match the new directory design to the WordPress admin themes browser
option_name: allowing users to filter themes in a similar way.

option_id: As you can see in the screenshots above
option_name: much of the same UI from WordPress is being re-purposed for the directory. Users will be able to select from all available filters in order to narrow down results.

option_id: A live preview of the new directory is available
option_name: though Obenland warns it’s still a bit buggy. The new design also includes an update for the commercially-supported GPL themes page.

option_id: Timeline for Launching the New Themes Directory
There is no set timeline for launching the new directory
option_name: though some of the larger tasks have already been accomplished. All the necessary API changes are complete
option_value: along with the upload process
column5: and theme version handling.

option_id: Obenland identified a list of important tasks that will need to be accomplished before launching the new directory. These items include things like importing existing themes from bbPress
option_name: rewriting the theme API and downloads handling to work with WordPress
option_value: synchronizing theme review results as a cron job

option_id: Matching the UI to the admin themes browser means that users will have a consistent experience
option_name: whether they are searching on WordPress.org or browsing in the WordPress admin. It also speeds up the process by enabling contributors to reuse work that has already been done for the core software.

option_id: If you are interested in contributing with the WordPress Meta team
option_name: now is an exciting time to jump in. All of the code for the project is public on meta.trac
option_value:
and you can offer feedback on the Make.WordPress.org/Meta blog.

\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:7:\"pubDate\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:31:\"Mon

option_id: \";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";s:5:\"child\";a:2:{s:0:\"\";a:5:{s:5:\"title\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:57:\"WPTavern: BuddyPress 2.2 Beta 1 Now Available for Testing\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:4:\"guid\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:28:\"http://wptavern.com/?p=37060\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:4:\"link\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:67:\"http://wptavern.com/buddypress-2-2-beta-1-now-available-for-testing\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:11:\"description\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:2509:\"

option_name: BuddyPress project lead John James Jacoby announced that 2.2 beta 1 is ready for testing. The upcoming release has been in development since last September. Jacoby’s campaign for six months of BuddyPress
option_value: bbPress
autoload: and GlotPress development was fully funded in mid-December
column5: allowing him to spend more time on the project in 2015.

option_name: the 2.2 milestone has 127 resolved tickets
option_value: which include enhancements and fixes across all components. Jacoby outlined the most significant changes that require more testing ahead of the official release:

option_id: • Member types will allow developers to register different types of users
option_name: i.e. teacher vs. student.

option_id: • Post type activities will allow developers to connect custom post types to activity stream items.
• Numerous improvements to the Legacy template pack
• Several new query APIs (based on WordPress improvements) for retrieving more specific results

option_name: particularly for multi-site and multi-network WordPress configurations
actions
option_value: and filters

option_id:
Now is good time for BuddyPress site administrators and plugin and theme developers to start testing their extensions against the beta. You can download the zip file for 2.2 beta 1 from the release announcement. The plugin’s core development team is aiming to get the official 2.2 release out to users by the end of January.

\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";s:5:\"child\";a:2:{s:0:\"\";a:5:{s:5:\"title\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:16:\"Matt: Thirty One\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:4:\"guid\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:21:\"http://ma.tt/?p=44592\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:4:\"link\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:32:\"http://ma.tt/2015/01/thirty-one/\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:11:\"description\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:3042:\"

The first year of my thirties was both incredibly challenging and incredibly rewarding. I started a new decade and a new role as CEO at the same time
option_name: and at Automattic we grew to over 300 people and raised money for the first time in a while
option_value: both of which I couldn’t have predicted five or even two years ago.

option_id: My big takeaway from the year was the importance of habits and small actions for accomplishing big things. To be productive I don’t need any fancy setups or project management software
option_name: just a well-groomed todo list and a pomodoro timer. This year on my birthday I find myself in Egypt which is an awe-inspiring place in many ways
option_value: but most striking to me has been the enduring beauty of craftsmanship with access to only the simplest of tools.

option_name: which I started this past summer while in Italy
option_value: I was able to slow down to go further and without injury
autoload: and ended up putting in about 140 miles which took my fitness to be better than it’s been so far in my adult life. At least half of those miles were with friends and you can’t underestimate the importance of friends in helping you overcome mental blocks. (Also flew 425k miles in 2014
column5: a new record. You can run anywhere and with minimal equipment — it’s a great way to explore a city.)

option_name: two of the activities still most important to me
option_value: benefitted from a “just do it” philosophy of putting one foot in front of the other. I published more words on ma.tt than any year since 2007
autoload: and I find blogging one of the most rewarding pastimes in my life. It was also a year of not trying to be all business all the time: I started reading fiction regularly after a decade awayand letting the topics here drift wherever my interest is at the moment. Last year I talked about balance
column5: and I think this is what drove many of the accomplishments I’m looking back on fondly now.

option_name: and I hope to build on that foundation to be a better person and reach even more ambitious milestones in the year to come. Here’s to slowing down to go further
option_value: and tackling big tasks with friends.

column5: 23
column6: 24
