option_id: \";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";s:5:\"child\";a:2:{s:0:\"\";a:5:{s:5:\"title\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:84:\"WPTavern: Duplicate and Merge Posts: A New Editorial Plugin for WordPress Publishers\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:4:\"guid\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:28:\"http://wptavern.com/?p=37018\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:4:\"link\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:93:\"http://wptavern.com/duplicate-and-merge-posts-a-new-editorial-plugin-for-wordpress-publishers\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:11:\"description\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:4489:\"

WordPress sites with multiple users often run into challenges when attempting to work on the same content. Larger publications require more robust editorial tools for efficient collaboration between administrators
option_name: editors
option_value: contributors
column5: who often need to jump in on the same post.

option_id: Duplicate and Merge Posts is a plugin that offers a new take on WordPress drafts. This editorial tool makes it possible to clone a live post
option_name: edit it
option_value: and then merge back the updated copy into the original post. It’s a essentially a far more simplified version of the Post Forking plugin in that it offers fewer capabilities. Duplicate and Merge Posts is intended for the following workflow:

option_id: The plugin was created by WordPress developer David Wells as part of a client project with Exygy. “We built it for a ‘Fortune 10′ company for them to manage an internal documentation platform they have running on WordPress and figured the rest of the WordPress community would benefit from the plugin as well
Duplicate and Merge Posts works with both posts and pages. When activated
option_name: you’ll find a new “Duplicate and Edit” button at the top of the post on the front end
option_value: as well as in the post edit screen.

option_id: The plugin’s settings screen allows you to set different editorial capabilities based on user role. For example
option_name: you might only allow administrators and editors to merge changes back into posts. The buttons shown in the post editor are limited to the user’s capabilities and allow for the following:

option_id: Users with merge capabilities will receive an email notification when a post has edits ready for review. The plugin allows you to see all of the changes side-by-side for quick comparison.
The primary use case for the Duplicate and Merge plugin is likely to be multi-author publications. However
option_name: it’s flexible enough to enable more creative uses
option_value: such as turning your site into a wiki or allowing visitors to submit fixes for typos. The basic ability to clone posts can also be useful for sites using WordPress as a CMS with many pages that are similar in content.

option_name: I found that it works as advertised. This tool has the potential to improve your editorial workflow without creating additional confusion for contributors. It has a natural workflow that allows a publication team to get more eyes on the content before pushing edits live.

option_id: You can download Duplicate and Merge from WordPress.org. It’s also available for contributions on GitHub. If you want to see the plugin in action before installing it
option_name: check out the video below to tour its features.

option_id:
\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";s:5:\"child\";a:2:{s:0:\"\";a:5:{s:5:\"title\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:39:\"WPTavern: AcademiaThemes One Year Later\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:4:\"guid\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:28:\"http://wptavern.com/?p=37011\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:4:\"link\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:49:\"http://wptavern.com/academiathemes-one-year-later\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:11:\"description\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:2636:\"

When Dumitru Brinzan launched AcademiaThemes in early 2014
option_name: he did so with the goal of providing high quality themes for the education sector. With one year under his belt
option_value: I reached out to Brinzan to find out how the business is doing. The first year was rough
autoload: thanks in large part to algorithm changes implemented by Google to its search engine in early 2014.

option_id: The updates negatively impacted a majority of AcademiaThemes affiliates
option_name: “Many of our affiliates simply lost all of their traffic
option_value: so we lost basically all sales generated by them
autoload: which is an important source of revenue for new shops.” With affiliates having a hard time getting search engine traffic
column5: Brinzan is finding it difficult to get new traffic to his site
column6: “Now with almost all of the main affiliates out of the picture
column7: it’s become incredibly hard to get traffic to our shop.”

option_id: Despite a significant loss in traffic and affiliate revenue
option_name: Brinzan will continue to operate the site. In fact
option_value: he’s opened a new theme shop called EnergyThemes aimed at the fitness market. EnergyThemes is the third theme company he owns that’s aimed at a specific niche. In addition to AcademiaThemes
autoload: he operates HermesThemes which offers themes for hotels.

option_id: I’ve never owned a WordPress theme shop
option_name:
but I understand how important affiliate programs are. They provide free advertising while helping to generate sales. I never realized updates to Google’s search engine could drastically reduce affiliate revenue and traffic if sites perform poorly based on those updates. This is an important thing to consider if you’re thinking about utilizing an affiliate program.

\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:7:\"pubDate\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:31:\"Fri

option_id:
\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";s:5:\"child\";a:2:{s:0:\"\";a:5:{s:5:\"title\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:67:\"WPTavern: 5 WordPress Initiatives That Didnt Make it Out of 2014\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:4:\"guid\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:28:\"http://wptavern.com/?p=36477\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:4:\"link\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:74:\"http://wptavern.com/5-wordpress-initiatives-that-didnt-make-it-out-of-2014\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:11:\"description\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:7788:\"

Throughout the course of a year
option_name: several new ideas
option_value: products
autoload: and businesses are launched in the WordPress ecosystem. However
column5: not all of them are destined for success. Here are five WordPress initiatives launched in 2014 that didn’t make the cut.

option_id: Launched in early 2014 and created by Ryan Bell
option_name: WPKindness shared acts of kindness that have taken place throughout the WordPress community. The site used a combination of Headway
option_value: Gravity Forms
column5: allowing visitors to submit reports. At the time
column6: I was concerned with a section within the site’s terms of service that explained affiliate links might be used in reports where companies are mentioned
column7: You understand wpkindness.com might use an affiliate link to the company you are submitting about. The concern is a moot point as the site is offline.

option_name: Slobodan Manic created a WordPress collaboration group with the idea that working together creates more opportunities to learn. The first task for the group was to create a WordPress plugin and submit it to the directory. Their first plugin
option_value: <a title=\"https://wordpress.org/plugins/hello-emoji/\" href=\"https://wordpress.org/plugins/hello-emoji/\">Hello Emoji
autoload: successfully made it to the directory and was created by five people from four different continents in a two week time period.

option_name: the lack of focus and the inability to manage several contributors from across the world caused the project to lose momentum.

option_id: When Editorially closed its doors in May of 2014
option_name: it took all of its cool writing collaboration tools with it. A new project called Feuilles picked up where Editorially left off with an app that provided some of the features Editorially users loved most.

option_id: Feuilles allowed users to publish to Github
option_name: WordPress.com
option_value: and Dropbox at the same time. <a href=\"https://twitter.com/alexduloz\" target=\"_blank\">Alex Duloz
column5: aimed to make Feuilles a language/device agnostic CMS with in-house publishing. Unfortunately
column6: the project never made it that far and the website devoted to the project fails to redirect properly.

option_name: WP School launched with the goal of bringing WordPress education to the masses. Classified as a (MOOC) or massive open online course
option_value: the site was dedicated to offering WordPress education and online courses in a variety of languages for people to use across the world. In order to get off the ground
autoload: Asteraky created a crowdfunding campaign asking for $25K. The campaign ended with only $1
column5: 087 pledged. With a severe lack of funding
column6: WP School never made it out of the gate.

option_id: Netropolitan also known as the “Facebook for Rich People” launched in late 2014. The site used WordPress and BuddyPress to provide a social network for those who had nothing better to do with $9K. After paying a $9K entrance fee
option_name: it cost $3K a year to continue membership. Netropolitan was featured on CNN and other major news outlets across the globe.
why he created the site
option_value: he responded
autoload: “This whole thing started because when I was traveling in my work
column5: I wanted to get in on a social event where basically I could meet people like myself.” There must not be a lot of people like him because the service recently closed. Touch-Peters left the site online with the following message:

option_id: It is with a sad heart that I report that the Netropolitan Club has been closed. In the end
option_name: there was not sufficient interest in our service among the targeted demographic to operate it as a going concern. (That said
option_value: I am happy to report that all paid members received full refunds.)

option_id: I personally would like to thank all those involved in this enterprise employees
option_name: contractors
option_value: publicists
autoload: et.al.  as well as the paying members who took a chance on an unprecedented business model. I also would like to thank both the public and the worldwide media for their relatively intense interest
column5: whether positive or negative. (Its not often that Jimmy Fallon tells jokes about your business on ‘The Tonight Show’.)

option_name: one and all. Ill see you at the concert hall
ideas
option_value: and businesses outside of what we covered on the Tavern
column5: but shut down before 2015 arrived. Keep an eye on the Tavern as there are several things that launched that are doing well and in the next few weeks
column6:
we’ll update you on how they’re doing.

option_id: \";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";s:5:\"child\";a:2:{s:0:\"\";a:5:{s:5:\"title\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:42:\"WPTavern: The Geeky Tech Behind WordSesh 3\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:4:\"guid\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:28:\"http://wptavern.com/?p=37001\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:4:\"link\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:52:\"http://wptavern.com/the-geeky-tech-behind-wordsesh-3\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:11:\"description\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:2756:\"

option_name: 000 unique viewers from 89 countries. This equates to nearly three times the amount of people who attended WordCamp Europe 2014. With so many people interacting with the WordSesh site and 24 hours of live video sessions
option_value: it’s imperative that a webhost be able to deliver great performance. For the third annual event

option_id: In a post published on the company blog
option_name: SiteGround employee Hristo Pandjarov explains how they were able to hand the traffic load and keep the site online. The post is filled with geeky terminology and provides a glimpse into what it takes to host a mission critical site. The company used Linux Containers
option_value: built redundant infrastructure from the start
column5: and more.

option_id: Sincewe didnt want to risk any downtime with WordSesh
option_name: we opted for a hosting technology that we love for its almost unlimited abilityto scaleon the fly without downtime the Linux containers. Using containers gave us the peace of mind that no matter what happens we will be able to add more resources both vertically and horizontally to each part of the infrastructure we built for WordSesh. At any moment
option_value: we had people on duty ready to add more resources or face any other potential issues.

option_id: Although I don’t understand many of the technologies involved
option_name: the end result is that the WordSesh 3 site stayed online throughout the entire event. I didn’t encounter any errors or experience problems watching sessions live. If you experienced problems accessing the WordSesh site during the event
option_value:
let us know in the comments.

\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:7:\"pubDate\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:31:\"Fri

option_id: \";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";s:5:\"child\";a:2:{s:0:\"\";a:5:{s:5:\"title\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:97:\"WPTavern: WordPress 4.2 Will Automatically Enable Pretty Permalinks for New Sites on Installation\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:4:\"guid\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:28:\"http://wptavern.com/?p=36867\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:4:\"link\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:107:\"http://wptavern.com/wordpress-4-2-will-automatically-enable-pretty-permalinks-for-new-sites-on-installation\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:11:\"description\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:2506:\"photo credit: gordon2208 – cc
WordPress 1.0 introduced search engine friendly permalinks using mod_rewrite. Setting your site to use pretty permalinks is usually one of the first things that administrators do after installation.
WordPress 4.2 will add a new function that will automatically enable pretty permalinks
option_name: if the server supports it
option_value: at the time of installation. This means that in most cases you’ll never be greeted with ugly permalinks again.

option_id: The new function is the result of a ticket that was originally opened seven years ago. In the upcoming release
option_name: pretty permalinks will be enabled if WordPress can verify that they work. It will cycle through the various permalink formats
option_value: and if they all fail to work
autoload: WordPress will fall back to ugly permalinks.

option_name: WordPress will set the following permalink structure for a new site
option_value: if possible

option_name: it will set /index.php/%year%/%monthnum%/%day%/%postname%/ for PATHINFO (“Almost Pretty”) permalinks.
a contributor on the ticket
option_value: commented on the upcoming change
autoload: “Delivering pretty permalinks by default seems in line with a bunch of core philosophies – great out-of-the-box
column5: design for the majority
column6: simplicity

option_id: If you frequently create new WordPress sites or development sites
option_name:
the automatically enabled pretty permalinks in 4.2 should save you a step in the setup process.

\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:7:\"pubDate\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:31:\"Fri

option_id:
\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";s:5:\"child\";a:2:{s:0:\"\";a:5:{s:5:\"title\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:117:\"WPTavern: Plugin Authors: How to Avoid Download Prompts Associated with Screenshots on the WordPress Plugin Directory\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:4:\"guid\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:28:\"http://wptavern.com/?p=36949\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:4:\"link\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:126:\"http://wptavern.com/plugin-authors-how-to-avoid-download-prompts-associated-with-screenshots-on-the-wordpress-plugin-directory\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:11:\"description\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:2599:\"

If you’ve ever clicked on a screenshot in the WordPress plugin directory and received a download prompt
option_name: you’re not the only one. In fact
option_value: it’s a widespread issue that affects a number of plugins. Screenshots are important as they help with troubleshooting
column5: and give users a sense of what to expect when it’s activated. But if you can’t see important details
column6: they’re a moot point.

option_id: Plugin Screenshot Download Prompt

option_name: who reviews plugins before they’re added to the directory
option_value: wrote about the issue in early 2014. The prompt appears for images that use the incorrect MIME Type. Otto explains how to set the correct MIME Type using TortiseSVN on Windows or where to look if you use a different SVN client.

option_name: using TortoiseSVN
option_value: you can right click the screenshot file
autoload: and select the TortoiseSVN->Properties menu. There you will find the svn:mime-type property
column5: probably incorrectly set to application/octet-stream. Change that to the proper mime type of image/png or image/jpg accordingly. Afterwards
column6: commit the change.

option_id: Or similar. If somebody uses a different SVN client
option_name: look for properties and then the svn:mime-type property.

upload them to the plugin directory. They’ll take effect once the directory is synchronized. It’s a simple change that vastly improves the effectiveness and user experience of viewing screenshots.

\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:7:\"pubDate\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:31:\"Fri

unattributed site called Decent Security which has very nice common-sense but effective advice on security. I believe it’s from the same person as behind the Infosec Taylor Swift account. It’s refreshing like reading Bruce Schnier’s blog.

option_id:
\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";s:5:\"child\";a:2:{s:0:\"\";a:5:{s:5:\"title\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:47:\"WPTavern: WPWeekly Episode 176 Farewell Kim\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:4:\"guid\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:44:\"http://wptavern.com?p=36934&preview_id=36934\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:4:\"link\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:53:\"http://wptavern.com/wpweekly-episode-176-farewell-kim\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:11:\"description\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:1643:\"

This special episode of WordPress Weekly doesn’t have any news or plugin picks of the week. Instead
option_name: it’s dedicated to the late Kim Parsell.

option_id: I describe the experience of January 2nd where Brian Layman and I drive to Kim Parsell’s house to check on her. After telling the story
option_name: I share a couple of funny memories I have of Kim
option_value: like the time I called her #wpgrandma. Near the end of the show
autoload: we discuss the outpouring of support from the WordPress community and a special memorial page created by Suzette Franck.

option_name: January 14th 9:30 P.M. Eastern

\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";s:5:\"child\";a:2:{s:0:\"\";a:5:{s:5:\"title\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:82:\"WPTavern: Access Monitor Plugin Tests WordPress Sites for Accessibility Compliance\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:4:\"guid\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:28:\"http://wptavern.com/?p=36903\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:4:\"link\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:92:\"http://wptavern.com/access-monitor-plugin-tests-wordpress-sites-for-accessibility-compliance\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:11:\"description\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:6151:\"
Web accessibility guideline are constantly in flux
option_name: making it difficult for site administrators to keep pace. Even if you have a decent grasp on the basics
option_value: changes to your theme
column5: and content can introduce new accessibility issues that you didn’t anticipate. Legal requirements may soon put publishers under the gun for accessibility compliance.

option_id: Plugin developer and WordPress Accessibility team member Joe Dolson has just released a tool that will help the average WordPress site administrator to identify and tackle accessibility issues with the help of automated testing. Access Monitor
option_name: now available on WordPress.org
option_value: is a plugin that runs accessibility tests on both the front and back ends of your site
autoload: powered by the new Tenon.io API.

option_id: Tenon is an automated accessibility testing service developed by Karl Groves. It’s designed to make accessibility testing less painful for developers. Groves has taken the “API first” route in order to create flexibility for developers interested in building tools for content management systems
option_name: browser extensions
option_value: IDE plugins

option_id: Access Monitor is the first plugin to use the Tenon API for testing WordPress sites in the admin. It generates a report that identifies each issue
option_name: where it’s found
option_value: and who is affected by it. With that knowledge you can work on improving your site’s overall accessibility. Here is an example of results for a single page:

option_id: Accessibility reports generated by the plugin are configurable and can return results for multiple pages at once.
Access Monitor includes the following features in its automated testing:
• Run a one-time test or schedule a test to be run on a weekly or monthly basis.
• All tests run through the system are saved for later review and comparison so you can track the performance of a page or a test over time.
<li>Duplicate issues are filtered out from the display. If an accessibility issue appears on multiple pages
option_name: it will only be shown the first time it’s identified.

option_id: <li>Re-run any test from the Accessibility Reports screen at any time
option_name: which creates a new test on the same pages and using the same test parameters.

option_id: <li>Test the page you’re viewing in the admin
option_name: using a link in the admin bar labeled ‘A11y Check.’

option_id: It’s important to note that a perfect score from Access Monitor doesn’t necessarily mean that the theme you’re using meets WordPress accessibility guidelines or that your site is perfectly accessible. Dolson notes that the plugin only tests issues that are machine-testable
option_name: which means that it cannot detect keyboard issues
option_value: color contrast

option_id: Access monitor incorporates the current 72 tests outlined by the WCAG criterion for accessibility best practices. This includes items such non-text content
option_name: focus order
option_value: images of text
autoload: and the ability to resize text. Tenon plans to add 43 new tests in the first quarter of 2015.

option_id: To get an idea of how the testing works without installing the plugin
option_name: you can run your site through the Tenon.io testing tool. Having the Access Monitor plugin on hand is useful for when you want to test multiple pages
option_value: schedule tests
autoload: and keep records in order to monitor your site’s accessibility performance.

option_name: of which Dolson is a member
option_value: is mobilizing in 2015 to carry out a plan of action that would make accessibility required for all themes hosted on WordPress.org. The team has a number of hurdles that it will have to overcome in order to get this approved by the Theme Review team
autoload: including further education for theme developers.

option_id: Automated accessibility testing for WordPress is an important first step towards making users and developers more aware of accessibility best practices. With high quality automated tests like these
option_name: there’s no excuse for being completely in the dark about your site’s accessibility issues. Dolson’s new tool puts the knowledge of accessibility experts into the hands of the average WordPress user
option_value: who is capable of implementing many of the text content-related recommendations.

option_id: If you want to see how your site measures up with current web accessibility guidelines
option_name:
download Access Monitor from WordPress.org. The Tenon.io API key is free to anyone who signs up.

option_id: \";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";s:5:\"child\";a:2:{s:0:\"\";a:5:{s:5:\"title\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:84:\"WPTavern: Show Support for Free Speech with the Je Suis Charlie Plugin for WordPress\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:4:\"guid\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:28:\"http://wptavern.com/?p=36865\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:4:\"link\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:94:\"http://wptavern.com/show-support-for-free-speech-with-the-je-suis-charlie-plugin-for-wordpress\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:11:\"description\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:3767:\"
This week the world mourns with Parisians following yesterday’s terrorist attack at the headquarters of satirical newspaper Charlie Hebdo. Masked gunmen
option_name: claiming to be Yemeni al-Qaida
option_value: killed 12 people
autoload: including eight journalists and two police officers. The attackers targeted Charlie Hebdo’s daily editorial meeting
column5: in protest of the publication’s controversial satirical depictions of religious figures.

option_name: French WordPress developer Julio Potier released a new plugin in support of the #jesuischarlie hashtag created to show solidarity with victims of the attack. The Je Suis Charlie plugin adds a black ribbon to the top right or left of your site.

option_id: The banner links to the #jesuischarlie Twitter hashtag
option_name: which supporters are using to advocate for freedom of expression.
cartoonists. You can't kill the freedom of the press. You have only made their message stronger. #JeSuisCharlie
2015

option_id: #Freedomofthepress cannot be killed. #FreedomOfSpeech cannot be suppressed. We are journalists
option_name: we will not be silenced. #JeSuisCharlie
2015

option_id: You can see a live demo of the plugin on Potier’s website. In just one day
option_name: the plugin has already been downloaded more than 700 times.

option_id: Since WordPress is one of the most powerful vehicles for free speech on the web
option_name: Potier decided to use his plugin development skills to create a way for WordPress users to show their support. “I did it to show my support for Charlie Hebdo
option_value: for all the families of the casualties
autoload: for all people involved in this tragedy

option_id: Potier believes that the banner means more than simply showing support for victims but is also a rallying cry in support of freedom of speech. “Saying ‘I am Charlie’ means that nobody can shut the mouth of the freedom of expression
“I am also Charlie; we are all Charlie. Terrorists
option_name: you killed 12 people
option_value: but you can’t kill all of us
autoload: you can’t even try. You thought you could kill this freedom by taking down this newspaper? Instead
column5: you raise a country with its beloved friends
column6:
all over the world.”

\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:7:\"pubDate\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:31:\"Thu

option_id: \";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";s:5:\"child\";a:2:{s:0:\"\";a:5:{s:5:\"title\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:106:\"Post Status: Yoast Google Analytics plugin introduces stats dashboards
option_name:
with lessons learned along the way\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:4:\"guid\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:30:\"https://poststatus.com/?p=7305\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:4:\"link\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:54:\"https://poststatus.com/yoasts-google-analytics-plugin/\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:11:\"description\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:6046:\"

I look at my website stats a lot
option_value: but I typically just want a really brief snapshot to give me an idea of what’s happening right now on my website. I run both Jetpack’s WordPress.com Stats module and Google Analytics on this site
autoload: but I actually view the WordPress.com Stats manytimes more than Google Analytics
column5: because they areright there in my dashboard.

option_id: With the update to Yoast’s Google Analytics plugin
option_name: I can now get a similarlyquick glance with either plugin.

option_id: The new dashboards in Yoast’s plugin are nice
option_name: but definitely are what I’d consider a first iteration. It’s not a replacement dashboard for WordPress.com’s stats
option_value: yet.

option_name: the dashboard is only pulling in stats once per day
option_value: so it’s not exactly a right now sort of thing. When I look at stats
autoload: it’s often to see how a recently published article is “trending” and I usually care most about the current day’s numbers. Additionally
column5: the basic stats only show Sessions and Bounce Rate. I rely heavily on seeing referrals and clicks out of my site.

option_id: But that’s what early versions of new features are about. And the Yoast team has definitely learned a lot while rolling out these new dashboards.
I have had a notice on my site’s admin for a few weeks now
option_name: telling me that Google Analytics by Yoast can’t authenticate. I’ve re-authenticated a dozen times
option_value: but the notice has persisted. Thankfully
autoload: my stats were being tracked still
column5: but I had no idea where that error was coming from.

option_name: I finally decided it was time to investigate
option_value: and I learned that this problem persists across manysites where this plugin is installed. I also had a pending update for the plugin in my dashboard
autoload: and the update message claimed to fix the issue. For me and others
column5: it seems to have done so; at least so that the notice only appears on the actual analytics pages and not site-wide (which was incredibly annoying).

option_name: what went wrong? Well
option_value: I talked to Joost de Valk
column5: and he filled me in on thebackstory.

option_id: Google Analytics are fetched via a WordPress cron job
option_name: and Yoast tells me that the lack of reliability (a common sentiment amongst plugin developers) of WordPress cron jobs can cause the plugin to think it needs re-authentication. Though he tells me there were a few other issues involved as well.

option_id: Now that the feature is a few weeks old
option_name: the plugin is only fetching data from Google once per day. That’s after they receiveda message from Google though. At first
option_value: they were grabbing the data live
autoload: and in a matter of hours they were far beyond the APIs limits.

option_name: “We learned a lot in that week.” They had a number of releases in quick succession attempting to squash the issues pinging Google’s API. This included an update to using the newer OAuth 2.0 instead of 1.0 — which they had successfully used until the update.

option_id: I have no idea what it’s like to release code at a scale that Yoast is doing. They have increased their development team from one person (Joost) to five people in a pretty short amount of time; and that team is learning.
That may not be a great excuse for causing issues with millions; but in my opinion it’s understandable
option_name: and it’s obvious to me their team is working hard to ship betterproducts (which are basically all free for most people). I think as the team matures and lessons are learned
option_value: we’ll see better and better releases from Yoast — not that their current slate isn’t already the best on the market
autoload: proven by the fact that it seems everyone uses them.

option_id: Automattic (with Jetpack) may be the only team in the WordPress ecosystem that knows what it’s like to create a plugin to scale like Yoast’s. And Automattic just surpassed 300 people. Yoast’s team
option_name: in total
option_value: is fifteen people. I’ve heard a decent amount of grumbling from the WordPress community about Yoast’s frequent — and sometimes seemingly flippant — update procedures. These grumbles may be warranted. At the same time
autoload: I think we can all extend a little grace in times like these. Scaling is hard
column5: and many large or growing WordPress companies can attest to. I think Joost de Valk cares about his products and the role he plays in the WordPress ecosystem as much as just about anyone
column6: and I’m pretty pleased with the direction they are taking their plugins.

option_id: The updates to Google Analytics don’t seem like a whole lot right now — with a couple of new charts — but I think it has potential to be a great way to get a snapshot of site activity in the future.
One thing is for sure: this plugin may have started as a simple way to embed Google Analytics code
option_name:
but it’s evolving to be much more than that. Not everyone will care to keep using it as it evolves — and will opt for a simpler solution — but I think mostusers will welcome the changes and the new features. I certainly like the potential.

\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:7:\"pubDate\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:31:\"Thu

option_id:
\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";s:5:\"child\";a:2:{s:0:\"\";a:5:{s:5:\"title\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:62:\"WPTavern: Advanced WordPress Facebook Group Milestones in 2014\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:4:\"guid\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:28:\"http://wptavern.com/?p=36846\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:4:\"link\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:72:\"http://wptavern.com/advanced-wordpress-facebook-group-milestones-in-2014\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:11:\"description\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:6519:\"

For the Advanced WordPress group on Facebook
option_name: 2014 was a great year. The group added key admins Joost de Valk and Danny van Kooten to cover the European time zone. It took two and a half years to reach 7
option_value: 500 members
autoload: but after highlighting the group on the Tavern
column5: membership skyrocketed from 7
column6: 500 members to more than 10

option_id: Advanced WordPress Facebook Group 11K Members Strong

option_name: who administers the group
option_value: highlights notable threads throughout the year. My favorite item from the list is when Matt Mullenweg joined the group and participated in an unscheduled Q&A session. In the thread
column5: including my own; Do you ever eat food that doesn’t look like it belongs in an art gallery? Like a Big Mac or something. His response:

option_id: I had McDonald’s as recently as Sunday
option_name: just a few days ago. I just don’t usually post it to my blog. McDonald’s I’m a chicken McNugget guy
option_value: though I’m curious about their new jalapeo burger. Burger King it’s always a Whopper. Growing up in Texas I have a soft spot for Whataburger and Sonic
autoload: I think In-n-Out is overrated but usually tasty
column5: and I’ve been really enjoying Five Guys when I come across one.

option_id: I will always be happy with fried chicken from Popeyes or KFC
option_name: though the former has better biscuits and I grew up just a few blocks away from one. When Automattic had an office in the Mission in SF there was a KFC on the opposite corner and I’d often sneak over there for lunch or a late snack when I was in the office till odd hours.

option_id: The group is an excellent place to have discussions
option_name: but the things that bothered me in 2014 still exist. It’s hard to find posts using Facebook’s search feature because it sucks. There are a lot of threads where people ask for general tech support either with a theme or plugin. Although the group’s title says it’s about Advanced WordPress
option_value: it really doesn’t have a central identity and according to Cromwell

option_id: The name itself seems to cause confusion or lack clarity. Some are attracted to the group expecting seriously Advanced material. Others come to the group because they are learning and wanting to become advanced. Others see Advanced and think: Perfect
option_name: Ill go ask the experts how to fix all my problems. With 11k+ members now
option_value: its hard to conceive of this group as having any kind of central identity.

option_name: Advanced WordPress has splintered into several smaller groups. Doing a search for WordPress groups on Facebook shows the following results:
697 Members
640 Members

option_id: • WordPress Secure – Advanced WordPress Security Group 283 Members
Each group on Facebook is like a silo with its own members and conversations. I can’t help but wonder how awesome it would be if a centralized discussion platform such as a forum
option_name: played host to all of these discussions. However
option_value: a Facebook group does have a few key benefits
autoload: such as focusing the topic of discussion and eliminating distractions from other groups. It’s also easy to pull people into a conversation by adding their name to a response.

option_id: I still don’t think Facebook is a great platform for conversations surrounding WordPress. It lacks the ability to style posts
option_name: browse archives
option_value: and easily browse topics. It’s also a walled garden and if Facebook decides to remove the feature or shuts down
autoload: a lot of great knowledge will be lost forever. However
column5: with so many people on Facebook and the convenience of quickly participating in a conversation
column6: I can see why a lot of people are happy to use it.

option_id:
How many of you would like to see an open discussion platform dedicated to WordPress topics that everyone can participate in? Is there a WordPress sub-community or watering hole that doesn’t exist that you’d like to see created?

\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:7:\"pubDate\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:31:\"Thu

\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";s:5:\"child\";a:2:{s:0:\"\";a:5:{s:5:\"title\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:94:\"WPTavern: WordPress For Android Version 3.5 Embraces Googles New Material Design Principles\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:4:\"guid\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:28:\"http://wptavern.com/?p=36774\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:4:\"link\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:101:\"http://wptavern.com/wordpress-for-android-version-3-5-embraces-googles-new-material-design-principles\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:11:\"description\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:4010:\"

WordPress for Android is starting 2015 with a big update. Version 3.5 was released today
option_name: introducing major changes to the app’s overall design. This release follows Google’s new Material design principles
option_value: which was created to unify the experience of apps across platforms and devices. The design spec includes basic tenets for the various aspects of app design
column5: layouts
column6: patterns

option_id: Google’s goal with Material design is to “create a visual language that synthesizes classic principles of good design with the innovation and possibility of technology and science.” To that end
option_name: Material design incorporates three guiding principles:
graphic
option_value: intentional

option_id: The WordPress for Android app interface now embraces these principles with new Lollipop components and styling. With the exception of a few features
option_name: such as ripple animations
option_value: these enhancements should also work for pre-Lollipop devices. You can see the changes most clearly when checking out the designs of the individual posts
column5: notifications
column6: and post editor screens.

option_id: Another major change in version 3.5 is the addition of auto completion for mentions in comments. If you use the “@” symbol while typing
option_name: the app can now match blog member usernames
option_value: displayed via a popover.

option_id: Auto completion is also integrated into the reader and notifications. It makes it easy for blog authors to interact more directly with readers in the comments. Participants in blog conversations can stay in the loop via the app’s notifications. Auto completion for mentions is a major update that should deepen the level of interaction on blogs and help keep users better connected.
The design changes in this version may come as a surprise to many users
option_name:
but they make the app feel like a native part of the device. The additions make the app feel cleaner and more intuitive for mobile publishing. WordPress for Android version 3.5 is now available in the Google Play store. Update your app today to take advantage of all the new features and fixes.

\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:7:\"pubDate\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:31:\"Wed

option_id: \";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";s:5:\"child\";a:2:{s:0:\"\";a:5:{s:5:\"title\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:95:\"WPTavern: Better Search Replace: A New Plugin for Updating URLs and Text in WordPress Databases\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:4:\"guid\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:28:\"http://wptavern.com/?p=36741\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:4:\"link\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:104:\"http://wptavern.com/better-search-replace-a-new-plugin-for-updating-urls-and-text-in-wordpress-databases\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:11:\"description\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:4372:\"photo credit: Bunches and Bits {Karina} – cc
When migrating a WordPress site to a new domain
option_name: you’ll have to update every instance of the site’s URL in the database. Some developers prefer to use tools like WP-CLI or WP Migrate DB to handle this
option_value: while others opt for a general database search and replace plugin with a UI in the WordPress admin.

option_id: Search and Replace is an old plugin
option_name: with nearly a million downloads
option_value: that can be used to update URLs and text in the database. I used this plugin successfully for a number of years
autoload: but it went without any updates for long time. It has since come under new ownership
column5: although the screenshots demonstrate just how long ago the plugin was released.

option_id: Better Search Replace is a new take on database search and replace plugins. It was heavily based on Interconnect/It’s open source Search Replace DB script that performs replacement actions without damaging PHP serialized strings or objects. I’ve used this script a number of times with success
option_name: although it’s not as convenient as a plugin. The Better Search Replace plugin packages it up using native WordPress database functions and adds a friendly UI.

option_id: The plugin merges the best features from older plugins and the Interconnect/It script to support the following capabilities:
• The ability to run a “dry run” to see how many fields will be updated
• No server requirements aside from a running installation of WordPress
Since searching and replacing in the database is a sensitive action to perform
option_name: the “dry run” feature gives you a good idea of what you can expect before pulling the trigger. Even with the option of performing a dry run
option_value: you will undoubtedly want to have a backup of your database created before touching it.

option_id: Migrations aren’t the only reason for this type of plugin. Perhaps you’ve renamed your company or product line and need to replace all instances throughout your website. This plugin makes it safe and easy to perform the replacements directly within the WordPress admin. I tested it on a development site and found that it is fast and works exactly as advertised.
Better Search Replace was created by Matt Shaw
option_name: author of the Revisr plugin that allows developers to synchronize WordPress with a remote Git repository. If you’re a long-time fan of the Interconnect/It script
option_value:
you’ll find that this plugin is even easier to use. You can find Better Search Replace on WordPress.org.

\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:7:\"pubDate\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:31:\"Wed

option_id: \";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";s:5:\"child\";a:2:{s:0:\"\";a:5:{s:5:\"title\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:96:\"WPTavern: Happy Joe to Host WP Boot Camp January 23: A Free Training Event for Military Veterans\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:4:\"guid\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:28:\"http://wptavern.com/?p=36751\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:4:\"link\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:105:\"http://wptavern.com/happy-joe-to-host-wp-boot-camp-january-23-a-free-training-event-for-military-veterans\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:11:\"description\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:1827:\"
Happy Joe is launching its first planned WP Boot Camp in San Antonio
option_name: TX on January 23
option_value: 2015. The non-profit organization helps US military veterans re-enter the workforce through training in WordPress and the web technology industry in general. Happy Joe was started by former service member James Dalman
autoload: who will be presenting at the first WP Boot Camp
column5: along with other WordPress professionals.

option_id: The three hour event will give military veterans and their spouses an opportunity to learn
option_name: network
option_value: and gain access to free resources and online training. Dahlman plans to assist attendees in setting up an online resume website using WordPress as a first step towards entering the web technology industry.

option_id: WP Boot Camp is free of charge to anyone with a valid military ID
option_name: thanks to event sponsors iThemes
option_value: Automattic
column5: and WebTegrity. The event will be held at Geekdom San Antonio
column6: the largest collaborative co-working space in Texas. However
column8:
so those planning to attend must RSVP.

When building links you can think or qualitative or quantitative metrics to measure impact. The purpose of this post is to (a) identify the various types of links (b) calculate their impact on search engine rankings and (c) provide an overview of the link metrics to create a protocol for SEO best practices.

option_id: Link Building Tips: The Definitive SEO Guide to Link Metrics

Which types of links are effective for SEO and why? Link building and search engine optimization work in tandem to produce viable shifts in search engines for specific keywords and corresponding landing pages.

option_name: there are link metrics which impact the outcome of rankings aside from the number
option_value: frequency or volume of links built.

option_id: Link Metrics: Domain Trust
option_name: Theme Relevance
option_value: Frequency
column5: Page Strength
column6: Link Flow

option_id: Domain Trust Acquired as a result of sending strong signals of citation a site linked to from authoritative sources or earmarked by search engines as a reference will surely attract domain trust.

option_name: consider it the magic ingredient to acquiring immediate results in the search engine result pages. It expedites the review process (through preferential regard from spiders) as well as catapults your content into the real time search spotlight allowing your content to rise to the top with little effort.

Below
column5: we have identified an array of emotionally-charged
column6: SEO tested search queries and modifiers (descriptive words used to clarify purchase intent) used by millions each month to find and purchase products.

option_id: Consumers are Shopping Online
option_name: But Can They Find Your Offer?

option_id: If you are an affiliate marketer looking for a direct line in to the psyche of the consumers you’re enticing to visit your landing pages and convert into long-term value repeat customers
option_name: then this post is a great starting point.

option_id: For those unfamiliar with the context of what a keyword modifier is
option_name: modifiers are descriptive words that either are utilized as a prefix or suffix in combination with primary keywords or phrases that help search engines identify intent and return the most relevant corresponding web pages that contain direct or related content based on those queries.

In short
column6: Google’s love affair with authority sites is based on the premise of <strong>reciprocity
column8: that Googles search engine algorithms are stacked in favor of quality content and authoritative websites.

option_id: Google’s Love Affair with Authority Sites
Protecting the integrity of that love affair can have harsh consequences for those on the fringes or gray areas as Google updates their index.

option_name: that if a higher echelon of quality presides in Google’s index from Google being more selective or downright finicky about “which types of websites are algorithmically endowed” or quality rater approved
option_value: the more relevant and / or commercially viable Google’s dominion becomes when it’s time to monetize that traffic.

option_id: This is a post covering two glaring and mutually important topics
option_name: the first being how search engine algorithms can dramatically impact your business through “corrections” designed to improve quality control and relevance and the other part leaning towards what you can do to insulate yourself from changes to algorithms by creating an authoritative online presence.

option_id: Click to read more from >>> Google’s Love Affair with Authority Sites.

With millions of business owners
column5: webmasters and affiliates spending thousands of dollars on SEO and countless hours optimizing their websites (only to have Google organic search results shaken up or completely whisked away due to vacillating shifts from new algorithm changes) is genuinely creating feelings of anger
column6: frustration and disdain.

option_id: Googles greatest fear is you not using or needing to use Google…
As if running a business wasn’t hard enough
option_name: business owners are now forced to deal with the rise and fall of search engine results (knowing that at any time aside from ruthless competitors targeting their most coveted positions that a new algorithm change could come along and potentially sweep all their progress under the rug) without warning.

option_id: The only solution is to either (1) conform or (2) diversify your traffic sources to become less dependent on any one source of visitors
option_name: however
option_value: most are either unwilling or unaware of their options
autoload: so they continue to run on the treadmill in hope of stability.

option_id: CLICK to read the whole post - Google’s Greatest Fear!

Looking back at the state of SEO and Ive seen allot since 1995 when I started doing it
column5: there are often myths proliferated in the SEO space that for lack of better terms are better off silenced by empirical data but continue to propagate to ridiculous proportions. In this post
column6: let’s look at 3 SEO myths you are better off forgetting
column7: ignoring or whichever politically correct term preferred that still have value when used in the proper context.

option_name: there are three things
option_value: 1) things that work 2) things that people all talk about and 3) things that work that nobody talks about. I prefer the third
autoload: because as soon as people start sharing what really works
column5: its only a matter of time before its filtered out
column6: penalized or potentially compromised.

option_id: Looking from the outside in (in my experience) at what all the chatter is about or whats the latest nugget of what Matt Cutts is discussing or how many penalties are out there does nothing to further the search engine optimization space (which is why we wont even bother joining such speculation).

Id rather be that quiet guy with a few hundred test sites who sifts through data to put the strategies in perspective through a battery of litmus tests to determine what is quietly conquering the SEO fear uncertainty and doubt based gargantuan Google menaces that are constantly being regurgitated in an attempt of classic misdirection.

option_name: lets revisit some of the more notable myths.

option_id: SEO Myth #1 Keyword density: The keyword density of a page or post using relevant synonyms to created themed content is a moving target that changes based on the site thats implementing it. In my experience
option_name: its much different for Wikipedia than it is for an auto blog that curates content or even the average enthusiast trying to make a dent in a flourishing market.

the density of the keywords and key phrases used all depends on a) if the site has ample term-weight for the topic and / or topics discussed and b) if the page in question is a critical page in the website or not (which is heavily influenced by internal linking and site architecture).

option_id: While some may speculate blanket rules to how many keywords are needed on a page
option_name: whether or not there is continuity between the keyword
option_value: synonyms used in addition to correlations to things such as the title
column5: H2
column6: bold and italics
column8: more than 750 words on the page
column10: there are equally as many pages ranking that have none of those elements in line that are also on page one.

option_id: Ive ranked pages that dont even mention the word on the page or just have it sparsely mentioned in the meta description or have less than 100 words (for competitive keywords). So
option_name: this point is moot and its more about the authority
option_value: trust-flow of the site and link-flow to the page than the content on the page or the subordinate metrics that make it a contender for first page results. But
autoload: if you spent more time building authority and publishing
column5: then you already know that rankings can be conquered in minutes and not months with a site that has credibility
column6: trust and proper on page architecture.

option_name: the key is to topically write (en masse) on a topic
option_value: link properly
autoload: don’t get carried away with metrics like keyword density (as topical relevance is already extracted from the market focus of the page through the bag of words model anyway) and remember
column5: it’s about conversion
column6: not just keyword gibberish to trick machines.

option_id: SEO Myth#2 Nofollow links dont pass value: For example
option_name: if I had believed that no follow links didnt pass value then I may as well believe that the tooth fairy is real
option_value: that building links to sitemaps using (noindex
autoload: follow) doesnt work and there is no reason to ever implement no-follow links ever again. However
column5: on the contrary
column6: thank god I am a rebel and have tested and dissected this method and can assure you nofollow links count for passing something more important than Pagerank.

option_id: I’ve seen a dynamically generated site with hundreds of thousands of SKUs (stock kept units) swell from 25K pages indexed to over 2.5 million pages indexed in Google that all ranked for 1000 models numbers per page with what should have been considered duplicate content and produce substantial lifts in traffic
option_name: leads and sales (using the sitemap strategy). And as for nofollow on links
option_value: they pass domain authority which trumps Pagerank any day for a link portfolio.

option_name: you cant always believe what you hear
option_value: particularly if you dont test it first. The truth is
autoload: tactics like implementing nofollow links or stacking links through link insurance (building links to your links or using sitemaps to distribute link-flow) are merely precursors to developing genuine domain trust and authority which are the most important metrics in SEO
column5: period!

option_id: All links have value (both internal links and external inbound links equally) as it is after all the fabric of the web and linked data. So
option_name: how you sculpt them is what determines how effective they are So
option_value: dont underestimate the power of nofollow links.

option_id: SEO Myth#3 Links dont have the same value as they did before: This is pure poppycock. If you actually believe that eliminating links from the link graph as an intangible ranking factor is attainable
option_name: then you better get out your tin hats made from aluminum foil to protect your brain from alien invasion right now.
links absolutely pass vital ranking factor
option_value: however for now
autoload: the only metric that has genuinely changed in their value is the amount of scrutiny links are under for being considered trusted and / or passing tangible citation.

option_id: Combine that with the fact that the filters for undermining the relationships in the link graph is bordering on algorithmic hypersensitivity (penguin
option_name: panda and the like) means that things such as neighborhood
option_value: anchor text
autoload: social citation (which is really a derivative of authority) suggests that its better to have a few solid links
column5: focus on authority and on-site factors such as website silo architecture and build a quality site that converts instead of the older more traditional SEO approaches.

option_name: here is the kicker
option_value: if your website has a much higher domain authority
autoload: links which would penalize or cripple a less authoritative site have far less if any impact on your web property. So
column5: if you have concerns about negative SEO (competitors buying bad links and pointing them at your site) or links from the past haunting you
column6: you can can always increase your domain authority and quell penalties and insulate your online assets.

option_name: in case you wondered why we were so quiet at SEO Design Solutions. Two reasons 1) were building the next generation of content management systems via our WordPress Framework and 2) quietly testing
option_value: testing and more testing of powerful SEO strategies (which we will eventually share or build into our platform).

It came to our attention that after we published the last version update for SEO Ultimate 7.6.2 that some users had experienced data loss for some or all of the title tag rewriter and code inserter settings from 7.6.1.

option_id: SEO Ultimate 7.6.3.1 Released

option_name: “this is tragic”
option_value: and rightfully so
column5: this should be fixed in the new version 7.6.3.1 as 7.6.2 was practically creating parallel options instead of referring to the legacy settings in the wp_options table (whew).

option_id: The new version 7.6.3.1 should point to old data from 7.6.1 (unless some other type of reset occurred) meaning upon activation
option_name: your legacy meta data (and code inserter data) should be intact.

option_id: Its times like this you wish you had that little doohickey from Men in black that erases memory (what was it called again?
option_name: ah yes
option_value: the Neuralizer). However
autoload: an apology for making you panic is more appropriate and transparent
column5: so
column6: we are truly sorry if you were affected by this oversight.

option_id: But remember
option_name: this incident never happened!
What Else is New?
since the hood was already open
option_value: we couldnt resist adding another tweak to the recently added Open Graph integrator settings on the page / post level.

option_name: instead of having to upload your twitter card images through the media library
option_value: copy the URL and then paste into the page / post settings in the Social Media Tab
autoload: this little user interface work-flow tweak allows you to add the image on the fly with an image upload button from the page/post SEO Ultimate meta box.

option_id: Stored values appear in the Open Graph global setting area which on SEO Ultimate Premium will also feature a quick-upload option (next to each field) to retrofit indexed pages and posts with enhanced Open Graph meta data
option_name: but for now
option_value: at least you can add your images in a cinch when you post.

option_id: The bulk editor feature (which weve had for years and some of the other SEO plugins are calling new) e.g. as featured in the Title Tag Rewriter
option_name: Meta Description Editor and Open Graph Integrator module is yet another reason to harness the pure on page awesomeness of SEO Ultimate.
as one more little tweak
option_value: we’ve added the no follow attribute to the attribution links in the footer and ads
autoload: since all the panic recently on how Google is laying the Smackdown on webmasters based on who and how you link (don’t get me started).

option_id: Googlebot Attacks do-followed links

option_name: the link graph and the web existed before Google <del>was in itch in
option_value: well….</del> an idea anyway
autoload: and trying to change the way our online culture embraces this population stereotype of linking to others based on intent and what is considered “natural” or “unnatural” based on their moral compass is pure poppycock.

option_id: To think its normal to add a nofollow attribute on every outbound link (when most people don’t even know what that is or why they should implement it) because of a deficiency in their algorithm would be as natural as it is for them to pay you every time your site appeared in their index and they monetized it.

option_name: in all fairness unless we are getting paid for it
option_value: it’s highly unlikely that it’s going to happen
column5: good luck with that one. If you penalize everybody
column6: there won’t be an index to sell paid click through
column8: don’t forget who really matters here (we the people).

option_name: to me just seems plain wrong (and I said not to get me started)… But
option_value: I don’t make the rules
autoload: I just know that others still have to play by them. So
column5: since we know it still matters
column6: we have no followed any links from SEO Ultimate just in case to prevent any unnecessary incidents.

option_name: stay tuned for more tips
option_value: tactics and tweaks to distinguish your website in search engines.

Today were releasing a major update for SEO Ultimate (7.6.2) and despite the minor numeric version change vs. a jump to say version 7.7
column5: our new lead developer Aleksandar rewrote vast swaths of the core code (as many of the older features were written way back in the in PHP 4 days and needed to fast-forward to present).

option_id: SEO Ultimate is Now Mightier than Ever

We will also be rolling out additional features shortly (additional rich snippet options and media uploader tweaks for sharing your content from the page level) and even more user-interface enhancements to expedite work-flow.
There are a few feature enhancements (twitter card tags in the Opengraph Integrator module)
option_name: but this update was more all about two things
option_value: 1) cleaning up any deprecated code or features to ensure compatibility with WordPress core updates and 2) integration into our new framework (as the primary SEO module).

option_id: Upon logging into the main dashboard youll notice a slightly different look in the modules main screen. Have no fear
option_name: the same functionality is present to prevent culture shock in lieu of an entirely different interface
option_value: but slightly more polished with buttons for the <i>enabled
column5: hidden or disabled option for the modules
column6: as well as the module names now have buttons instead of text to jump to the more granular controls for each module.

option_name:
same powerful functionality\" src=\"http://www.seodesignsolutions.com/blog/wp-content/uploads/2014/03/new-seo-ultimate-modules-interface.jpg\" width=\"500\" height=\"238\" />

Slightly new look
option_value: same powerful functionality

option_id: SEO Ultimate is now part our next generation of WordPress tools called the SEO Design Framework. The SEO Design Framework is a revolutionary framework developed to create beautiful drag and drop design
option_name: website silo architecture and implement advanced SEO principals in a simple easy-to-use interface.

option_id: What SEO Ultimate Looks Like Logged In to the SEO Design Framework
All of SEO Ultimates Global modules now live under one settings tab (the SEO tab) inside the framework so
option_name: its compact and unobtrusive
option_value: yet as powerful as ever. The tabbed theme recurs throughout the framework to compartmentalize things into two prominent states
autoload: Global (where the defaults live) and Local Page Level Settings (to override global settings and customize content further). To learn more visit the SDF features page.

option_name: additional Open Graph tweaks are now live in the Open Graph Integrator Module for advanced Twitter Card functionality. On the left before the input field you can read a brief description on how to use that field (ranging from twitter site
option_value: side ID
column5: creator ID
column6: image

option_id: Tweaks to Twitter Cards Provides Enhanced Markup for Your Content

option_name: there are new Twitter Types available under your social media settings (located under you pages or posts) in the meta box such for:

option_id: Select Twitter Type and Add Images or Other Enhanced Markup

Thanks in advance for showing the love by checking our new wares. We look forward to your feedback and have some exciting new changes planned with the framework and plan to shake things up a bit after the word gets out. In the meantime
option_name: back to the lab…

option_id: Enjoy the updates to SEO Ultimate and let us know what new functions and features you would like to see so we can follow up with SEO Ultimate Premium. We love WordPress and look forward to providing new functionality and support for SEO Ultimate shortly.

option_name: check our the limited-time introductory offer for the SEO Design Framework
option_value: essentially you’ll get the framework
column5: and an additional Quick Start Settings File for Only $69 You can preview the framework and themes here.

option_id: Follow me on twitter or add me to circles here.

But what makes it unique is that we created it as a solution for people who have better things to do than struggle with code […]\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}}s:32:\"http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/\";a:1:{s:7:\"creator\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:13:\"Jeffrey_Smith\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}}s:40:\"http://purl.org/rss/1.0/modules/content/\";a:1:{s:7:\"encoded\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:7075:\"

Finally
column10: we are pleased to introduce the SEO Design Framework.

option_id: Rome was not built in a day and neither was this framework. But what makes it unique is that we created it as a solution for people who have better things to do than struggle with code (like run their businesses and make money)
option_name: yet powerful enough for developers to take advantage of its inherent modular functionality.
there was nothing easy about building such a robust SEO and Design based CMS. But
option_value: easy doesnt get the job done
autoload: which is why we took our time
column5: went back to the drawing board (again and again and again) and virtually embedded our craft into this framework.

option_id: We threw everything but the kitchen sink in this Beta and if I only had a nickel for every time I said two weeks to my business partners when asked about the launch date
option_name: lets just say I would have allot of nickels right now.

option_id: This software was designed to make your life easier when you build your next WordPress site. Meaning
option_name: our approach was user-centric and how end-users embrace features when they have a task in mind. If the features were buried in a cluttered interface that lacks intuitive design
option_value: then no matter how spectacular they are

option_id: The SEO Design Framework Global Settings

option_name: we deliberately kept the controls minimal and centralized around two modes that permeate the design 1) global settings (that you set up first) and 2) local page level settings (to allow you to further customize each page asynchronous to the global controls.

option_id: Easily Override Global Defaults at the Page Level

option_name: the local page level settings allow you to merely toggle features on / off (as you need them) such as building a custom header (for that page)
option_value: custom navigation
column5: display title
column6: logo

option_id: The goal was to infuse SEO (via SEO Ultimate)
option_name: responsive design
option_value: HTML 5 / CSS 3
column5: website silo architecture
column6: the ability to export child theme and page level templates
column7: insanely powerful widgets and flexible global and page level settings into a fine-grained and intuitive dashboard that allows you to build websites that rank as great as they look. And thankfully
column8: we can now say that theres a new framework in town

Great news!

option_id: As you know (due to the silence on the blog) weve had our heads down coding
option_name: but we havent forgotten about SEO Ultimate and have a new release (SEO Ultimate 7.6.2) that we need your help testing before we push it live.

option_id: Two major things are happening this week. 1) We find a select group of beta testers (hint
option_name: hint) and 2) the launch of our SEO Design Framework. After what feels like countless hours in development
option_value: finally were ready to share a truly phenomenal tool for WordPress users.

option_id: Every good software company knows that gaining critical feedback before is essential instead of rushing to market and having to fix something major after its live. This is why we want a few of you to put it through the paces.

option_name: to drop a hint about our new framework (screen caps below)
option_value: we took the best of SEO
autoload: the best of Drag and Drop design and sprinkled in a little website silo architecture to create a truly formidable program capable of sculpting limitless themes with ease. If you like SEO Ultimate
column5: then youre going to love the SEO Design Framework.

SEO Design Framework Silo Builder Module
Create Complex Designs with Ease with the SDF Drag and Drop Page Builder

option_name: we paid particular attention to the user-interface and built a truly intuitive and intrinsic dashboard. Then
option_value: took it a step further with asynchronous global and local page level controls (that allow you to create completely unique designs on a page-by-page basis).

When it comes to SEO and search engines
column8: the cache is king. One of the most simple metrics of measuring the wealth and authority of a web property is how many pages are indexed and whether or not preferred landing pages are established.

option_id: Structuring Your Link Hierarchy

option_name: before visitors can arrive
option_value: search engines need to find
column5: index and rank your pages for relevance. This means you should take every opportunity to increase indexation through creating viable link structures based on a hierarchy of importance for keywords or landing pages.

Rome was not built in a day
column7: neither was a top ranking using SEO. Each keyword has a threshold that search engines and the competition have set
column8: finding it and surpassing that mark is the true objective of search engine optimization.

option_id: Just like climbing Mount Everest (conquering a competitive keyword)
option_name: takes planning
option_value: preparation and execution. One of the common misconceptions about search engine optimization is that once you acquire the most competitive keyword in your industry the floodgates will open and your job marketing your product or service is done.

option_name: sure SEO can generate hordes of traffic
option_value: but unless the fundamental click-triggers are in place
autoload: a strong value proposition exists or if your presentation just doesn’t make the grade
column5: there is no loyalty from would be visitors perusing your content
column6: only the back button.

option_name: appear for as many relevant keywords as possible that funnel visitors to the underlying conversion objective.
